{{Infobox person | name = Hayabusa | image = Hayabusa FMW.jpg | caption = Eiji Ezaki as Hayabusa at a [[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW]] show in April 1999 | birth_name = Eiji Ezaki | birth_date = {{birth date|1968|11|29}} | birth_place = [[Yatsushiro, Kumamoto]], [[Japan]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|3|3|1968|4|4|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Kamata, Tokyo]], Japan |death_cause = [[Cerebral hemorrhage]] | residence = | occupation = Professional wrestler, musician, stage actor | years_active = 1987–2001 (professional wrestler)
2001–2016 (musician)
2005 (actor) | spouse = {{marriage|Harumi Ezaki|1997|2004|reason=divorced}} | children = 2 | module = {{Infobox professional wrestler|child=yes |names=Darkside of Hayabusa
Eiji Ezaki
H
Hayabusa |height={{convert|1.83|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |weight={{convert|75|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |resides= |billed= |trainer=[[Takashi Ishikawa]]
[[Tarzan Goto]]
[[Rey Misterio, Sr.]]
[[Ultimo Dragon]] |debut=November 2, 1987{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/Hayabio.html|title=Hayabusa's Biography|publisher=BAHU's FMW World}}{{Efn|The exact date of Hayabusa's professional wrestling debut is disputed. FMW's website has officially listed Hayabusa's debut as November 2, 1987, although most of the sources have recorded his debut as May 5, 1991.}} |retired=October 22, 2001 }} }} {{nihongo|'''Eiji Ezaki'''|江崎 英治|Ezaki Eiji|November 29, 1968 – March 3, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://ameblo.jp/fushichou/|script-title=ja:ハヤブサオフィシャルブログ「愛と勇気とあるこーる」|publisher=the official blog of Hayabusa|language=Japanese}} was a [[Japan]]ese [[professional wrestler]], [[actor|stage actor]], [[musician]] and [[professional wrestling]] [[promoter (entertainment)|promoter]], better known under the [[ring name]] {{nihongo|'''Hayabusa'''|ハヤブサ|Hayabusa|"Falcon"}}. He was best known for his time with [[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling]] (FMW), where he primarily wrestled throughout his career and was the [[franchise player]] of the company between 1995 and 2001. Ezaki initially competed for FMW as a low-carder between 1991 and 1993 before travelling to Mexico where he developed the "Hayabusa" [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick|character]] and his signature wrestling style during his time with [[lucha libre]] organizations. He returned to FMW in 1995 and received a significant [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Push|push]] as the face of the company, winning his first [[FMW Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship|Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship]] later that year. He spent much of 1996 on the sidelines due to injury and lost the majority of his high-profile matches upon his return. He started gaining popularity and championship success in 1997 and won the Double Championship in 1998 and held the title for most of the year. He developed alter egos such as "The Darkside of Hayabusa" in 1996 and the unmasked "H" in 1999. His career ended in late 2001 after a botched [[moonsault]] left him paralysed. He was a five-time [[professional wrestling championship#World championships|world champion]] in FMW as he won the Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship [[FMW Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship#Title History|three times]], [[FMW Independent Heavyweight Championship|Independent Heavyweight Championship]] [[FMW Independent Heavyweight Championship#Title History|one time]]{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/Independent.html|title=FMW Independent Championship official title history|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-25}} and the [[WEW Heavyweight Championship]] [[WEW Heavyweight Championship#Title history|one time]].{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/wewworld.html|title=WEW World Independent Championship official title history|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-25}} He also became a [[FMW Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship#Title History|two time]] [[FMW Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship|Brass Knuckles Tag Team Champion]], a [[WEW World Tag Team Championship#Title history|two time]] [[WEW World Tag Team Championship|WEW World Tag Team Champion]],{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/FMWTag.html|title=FMW/WEW World Tag Team Championship official title history|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-25}} a [[FMW World Street Fight 6-Man Tag Team Championship#Title history|two time]] [[FMW World Street Fight 6-Man Tag Team Championship|World Street Fight 6-Man Tag Team Champion]] and a [[WEW 6-Man Tag Team Championship#Title history|two time]] [[WEW 6-Man Tag Team Championship|WEW 6-Man Tag Team Champion]].{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/wew6man.html|title=FMW/WEW Six-Man Tag Team Championship official title history|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-25}} He also won [[All Japan Pro Wrestling]]'s [[All Asia Tag Team Championship]] [[All Asia Tag Team Championship#Title history|once]].{{cite web|url=http://www.all-japan.co.jp/champ/アジアタッグ王座|title=All Asia Tag Team Championship official title history|publisher=[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-25}} In his post-retirement years, Ezaki promoted the Wrestling Marvelous Future (WMF) promotion, which spun off from FMW, but the promotion was a failure and ended in 2008. He headlined many [[List of FMW supercards and pay-per-view events|pay-per-view events]] for FMW including the company's premier show [[FMW Anniversary Show|Anniversary Show]] a record six times, consecutively for four years between [[FMW 9th Anniversary Show|9th]] and [[FMW 12th Anniversary Show|12th]] editions of the event. ==Professional wrestling career== ===Early years (1987–1991)=== Trained by former [[All Japan Pro Wrestling]] star and sumo wrestler [[Takashi Ishikawa]], Eiji Ezaki made his professional wrestling debut at an independent show on November 2, 1987, teaming with [[Mr. Gannosuke|Masashi Honda]] against three upper classmen. He and Honda would struggle in the very small indy circuit for four years before joining [[Frontier Martial Arts Wrestling]]'s dojo, headed by another former AJPW alumnus [[Tarzan Goto]]. ===Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling=== ====Early years (1991–1993)==== Ezaki made his FMW debut on May 5, 1991, where he teamed up with [[Damian 666|Amigo Ultra]] to defeat El Pandita and Yukihide Ueno in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types|tag team match]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=165275|title=FMW results - May 5, 1991|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} As is customary for rookies to lose matches in professional wrestling, especially [[puroresu]], Ezaki lost the majority of his matches throughout the year. Ezaki got his first win in FMW against fellow rookie [[Mr. Gannosuke|Masashi Honda]] on June 29.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=165298|title=FMW results - June 29, 1991|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} The two competed in many matches including the opening match of FMW's [[FMW 2nd Anniversary Show|2nd Anniversary Show]] on September 23, which Ezaki won.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/miscfmw.html#fall91|title=Fall Spectacular 1991 results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-24}} His next major show appearance was at a FMW and [[World Wrestling Association]] co-promoted interpromotional event on May 16, 1992, where Ezaki represented FMW with [[Mr. Gannosuke]] and [[Psicosis II|Ultra Taro]] against WWA's Los Mercenarios Americanos (Mercenario I, Mercenario II and [[Louie Spicolli|Mercenario III]]) in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Multiple man teamed matches|six-man tag team match]], which Ezaki lost after being pinned by Spicolli.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/miscfmw.html#fmwla|title=FMW/WWA in Los Angeles results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-24}} At September's [[FMW 3rd Anniversary Show|3rd Anniversary Show]], Ezaki and Gannosuke lost to [[Chris Jericho]] and Kevin Faule.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/miscfmw.html#fall92|title=Fall Spectacular 1992 results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-24}} Ezaki participated in the company's [[FMW 4th Anniversary Show|4th Anniversary Show]] on May 5, 1993, where he defeated [[Koji Nakagawa]] in the opening match.{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-5.5.93.html|title=FMW Kawasaki Stadium, 5/5/93|publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-24|author=Ryan Mancuso}} In September 1993, Ezaki participated in a tournament for the inaugural [[Independent World Junior Heavyweight Championship]], where he lost both matches in his block against Koji Nakagawa{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=25859|title=FMW results - September 17, 1993|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} and Battle Ranger Z.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=62387|title=FMW results - September 25, 1993|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} His last match in FMW during this tenure was a win against [[Masato Tanaka]] on September 27,{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=62547|title=FMW results - September 27, 1993|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} before [[Atsushi Onita]] sent Ezaki overseas to learn the [[lucha libre]] style in Mexico. ====North American excursion and return (1993–1995)==== {{Quote box|quote="A really good first impression for Hayabusa, but it was clear that he was still pretty green. He was still working on what moves he should keep using, and moves that he should ditch. Thankfully, he got rid of the Shooting Star Press as this match wasn’t the only time he had miscalculated the move."|source={{small|Larry Csonka of 411mania on Ezaki's performance in the [[Super J-Cup#1994|1994 Super J-Cup]].}}|align=right|width=30%}} Ezaki adopted the '''Hayabusa''' [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick|character]] in December 1993 while in Mexico. While there, he learned the [[lucha libre]] style from wrestling instructor [[Rey Misterio, Sr.]] Ezaki wrestled for the [[World Wrestling Association]], [[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide|Asistencia Asesoria y Administration]] (AAA) and [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) during his time in Mexico. He then returned to Japan to participate in the [[Super J-Cup#1994|1994 Super J-Cup]] tournament for [[New Japan Pro Wrestling]] (NJPW), where he competed as Hayabusa in Japan for the first time to test how the crowd reacted to his character in Japan. He faced [[Jyushin Thunder Liger]] in a losing effort in a well received first round match of the tournament.{{cite web|url=https://411mania.com/wrestling/tremendous-tirades-super-j-cup-1994/|title=Super J-Cup 1994 review|publisher=411mania|accessdate=2017-10-24|date=September 6, 2004|author=Larry Csonka}}{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/newjapan/jcup.html#1|title=Super J-Cup 1994 tournament brackets|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-24}} The following month, Hayabusa debuted for CMLL on May 17 by teaming with [[Ringo Mendoza]] and La Sombra to defeat Javier Cruz, Panico and Tornado Negro in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Series variations|two out of three falls match]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=69589|title=CMLL Martes de Coliseo event|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} He teamed with Super Astro in the number one contender's [[CMLL World Tag Team Championship#1994|tournament]] for the vacated [[CMLL World Tag Team Championship|World Tag Team Championship]], where the duo lost to [[El Dandy]] and [[Negro Casas]] in the opening round.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=70020|title=CMLL results - July 22, 1994|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} During his time in Mexico, [[Victor Quinones]] would offer Ezaki a contract to defect to [[IWA Japan]], but declined, showing loyalty to FMW. He appeared as Hayabusa in FMW for the first time at [[Summer Spectacular (1994)|Summer Spectacular]] on August 28, 1994 by defeating [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]].{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/miscfmw.html#summer94|title=Summer Spectacular 1994 results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-24}} He then returned to CMLL to team with fellow Japanese wrestler [[Último Dragón]] in the [[CMLL tag team tournaments#Copa de Oro 1994|1994 Copa de Oro]] on October 25 in a loss to eventual winners [[Apolo Dantés]] and El Dandy in the quarter-final.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/index.php?id=26&nr=2316|title=Copa de Oro 1994 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} The following month, Hayabusa and Dragon participated in the number two contender's tournament for the World Tag Team Championship, where they defeated [[El Felino]] and [[Mano Negra (wrestler)|Mano Negra]] in the first round{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=70183|title=CMLL results - November 11, 1994|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} before losing to [[El Satánico]] and [[Emilio Charles Jr.]] in the quarter-final.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=70187|title=CMLL results - November 18, 1994|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-24}} He would remain in Mexico until December 1994. Between January 1995 and April 1995, Ezaki wrestled in the United States, mainly in the [[Florida]] area. During this time, the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) was interested in Ezaki and offered a tryout, but he declined and remained with FMW. ====Initial push and injuries (1995–1996)==== Ezaki was scheduled to make his full-time return to FMW as Hayabusa at the company's [[FMW 6th Anniversary Show|6th Anniversary Show]] against [[Mike Awesome|The Gladiator]] on May 5, 1995. However, he was chosen by FMW's new owner [[Shoichi Arai]] to fill the spot as Atsushi Onita's opponent in Onita's retirement match at the event as Onita wanted his final opponent to succeed him as the promotion's [[franchise player|ace]] after Onita's originally supposed opponent [[Tarzan Goto]] left FMW and there was no main event star left to be Onita's opponent. Hayabusa returned to FMW at the 6th Anniversary Show, where he unsuccessfully challenged Onita for the [[FMW Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship|Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship]] in an [[Professional wrestling match types#Steel cage match|exploding cage]] [[Professional wrestling match types#Barbed Wire Massacre|barbed wire]] [[Hardcore wrestling#Rules|deathmatch]].{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/fmwanniv.html#6th|title=6th Anniversary Show results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-25}} During the match, Ezaki managed to kick out of Onita's ''[[Powerbomb#Thunder Fire Powerbomb|Thunder Fire Powerbomb]]'' and gave a huge fight. He was rushed to the hospital on a stretcher due to suffering severe burns but became Onita's successor as the ace of FMW. Hayabusa returned to the company on May 17 by teaming with Katsutoshi Niiyama against [[Lethal Weapon (professional wrestling)|Lethal Weapon]] members The Gladiator and [[Horace Hogan|Horace Boulder]] in a losing effort to begin his first [[Feud (professional wrestling)|rivalry]] in the company with Lethal Weapon.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45067|title=FMW results - May 17, 1995|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-25}} He was the leader of the new generation of FMW wrestlers including Niiyama, Masato Tanaka and [[Tetsuhiro Kuroda]] and Koji Nakagawa. He wrestled the group's members in several tag matches for the next one month after Lethal Weapon questioned his ability to become the ace of FMW and vowed to take over the company. He initially struggled to gain a fanbase after Onita's loyal fans refused to accept him but Hayabusa got to impress the Japanese fans by debuting the ''[[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Corkscrew 450° splash|Phoenix Splash]]'' against Lethal Weapon member [[Ricky Fuji]] during a match on May 28.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45076|title=FMW results - May 28, 1995|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-25}} Hayabusa's team lost but the ''Phoenix Splash'' was heavily promoted by the Japanese media, which helped FMW in regaining the fanbase and Ezaki started becoming popular due to his high-flying skills. Just one month after his re-debut, Ezaki was [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Book|booked]] to win the promotion's top title, the vacant Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship by defeating Lethal Weapon member [[Hisakatsu Oya]] on June 27 by debuting his new finishing move, ''[[Suplex#Sitout suplex slam|Falcon Arrow]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45075|title=FMW results - June 27, 1995|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-25}} However, he immediately vacated the title due to injury but a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Angle|storyline]] was created that he vacated it because he wanted to beat Gladiator and all the members of the [[W*ING Alliance]].{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/brassknux.html|title=FMW Brass Knuckles Championship official title history|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-25}} The title was put up for grabs in the [[FMW tournaments#Grand Slam Tournament|Grand Slam Tournament]], an eight-man tournament in the [[round-robin tournament|round-robin format]] and Ezaki was put in the tournament. However, before the tournament started, Ezaki was severely injured by The Gladiator in a match on July 30 but he insisted that he would compete in the tournament.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45095|title=FMW results - July 30, 1995|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-25}} Ezaki started the tournament on August 22 by defeating Masato Tanaka.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45096|title=FMW Grand Slam - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} He won his next match against [[Kintaro Kanemura|W*ING Kanemura]] on August 25 to gain four points.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45098|title=FMW Grand Slam - Tag 3 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} He competed against Hisakatsu Oya to a thirty minute time limit draw{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45103|title=FMW Grand Slam - Tag 8 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} and defeated The Gladiator{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45106|title=FMW Grand Slam - Tag 11 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} and Katsutoshi Niiyama to gain nine points in the tournament.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45107|title=FMW Grand Slam - Tag 12 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} He suffered his first loss in the tournament against [[Corporal Kirchner|Super Leather]]{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45110|title=FMW Grand Slam - Tag 15 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} and then defeated Mitsuhiro Matsunaga to qualify for the final.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45115|title=FMW Grand Slam - Tag 20 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} He lost to Gladiator in the final round of the Grand Slam on September 25.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45116|title=FMW Grand Slam - Tag 21 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} Ezaki competed against W*ING and Lethal Weapon members in various tag team matches, [[Hardcore wrestling#Rules|street fights and deathmatches]] throughout the rest of the year and early 1996 before taking time off due to multiple injuries.{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/FMWNewGen.html|title=FMW official results (5/17/95 - 5/5/96)|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-26}} Despite the injury, Hayabusa returned to FMW on March 30 to rescue Jason the Terrible from an assault by [[Mr. Pogo]] and [[The Headhunters (professional wrestling)|The Headhunters]] to set up the [[Card (sports)#Main event|main event]] for the company's [[FMW 7th Anniversary Show|7th Anniversary Show]] on May 5, where he teamed with Masato Tanaka to take on Pogo and [[Terry Funk]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Hardcore-based variations|no rope explosive barbed wire time bomb land mine double hell death match]] and the winner would receive one million [[yen]]s. Hayabusa was [[Pin (professional wrestling)|pin]]ned by Funk after a brutal match.{{cite web|url=http://www.quebrada.net/reviews/fmw19960505.html|title=FMW 7th Anniversary Show Review|publisher=Quebrada|accessdate=2017-10-26}}{{cite book|author1=George Napolitano|title=Hot Spots and High Spots|date=2011|isbn=1770900640|pages=282–294|language=English|chapter=Mat Classics}} After the one-off return, Ezaki continued to heal his injuries and did not compete in FMW for the next three months. On August 1, he made his return to full-time competition by defeating Koji Nagakawa at the [[Summer Spectacular (1996)|Summer Spectacular]] event.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/miscfmw.html#summer96|title=Summer Spectacular 1996 results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-26}} On September 11, Ezaki debuted an [[alter ego]] called '''Darkside Hayabusa''' during a street fight against [[Hido (wrestler)|Hido]] at a W*ING show, which Ezaki won.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45388|title=WING results - September 11, 1996|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} On September 20, [[Jinsei Shinzaki]] of [[Michinoku Pro Wrestling]] challenged Hayabusa to a match, who Hayabusa lost to in the main event of Michinoku Pro Wrestling's ''These Days'' event.{{cite web|url=https://411mania.com/wrestling/the-puro-review-michinoku-pro-wrestling-these-days/|title=The Puro Review: Michinoku Pro Wrestling: These Days|work=411Mania|author=Jake Metcalfe|date=May 16, 2002|accessdate=2018-10-02}} This marked the beginning of a future friendship between the two. Following the match, [[The Great Sasuke]] challenged Hayabusa to a match at FMW's [[Year End Spectacular (1996)|Year End Spectacular]] on December 11, which Ezaki won.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/miscfmw.html#end96|title=Year End Spectacular 1996 results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-26}} ====The Ace of FMW (1997–1998)==== In the meanwhile, Terry Funk formed the Funk Masters of Wrestling group, which replaced Lethal Weapon as the new antagonist group and Hayabusa wrestled the group's members throughout the rest of 1996 and much of 1997. Ezaki's former friend Mr. Gannosuke returned to FMW and attacked Hayabusa after Hayabusa and Katsutoshi Niiyama lost to The Headhunters in a tag team match on January 5, 1997.{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/Hayabusa2.html|title=Hayabusa's Biography: Part Two|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-27}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=20908|title=FMW New Generation Year - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} As a result of the attack, Hayabusa began a lengthy and emotional rivalry with Gannosuke that would continue for the rest of his career. During this time, Ricky Fuji sided with FMW after the demise of Lethal Weapon and became an ally of Hayabusa. On March 19, Hayabusa got his first title shot in nearly two years as he and Fuji challenged The Headhunters for the [[FMW Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship|Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship]] in a losing effort.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=34438|title=FMW Winning Road 1997 - Tag 6 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-26}} The following month, Ezaki served as the centerpiece of FMW during a meeting with [[All Japan Pro Wrestling]] owner [[Giant Baba]] to begin a partnership between AJPW and FMW and subsequently made his AJPW debut at the [[Champion Carnival|1997 Champion Carnival]] by teaming with [[Yoshinobu Kanemaru]] against [[Kentaro Shiga]] and [[Yoshinari Ogawa]] in a losing effort.{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/AJReview-ChampionCarnival97.html|title=Champions Carnival 1997 review |publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-27}} This paved the way for wrestlers of AJPW and FMW to sporadically appear in both companies and began Hayabusa's occasional appearances in AJPW. Hayabusa defeated Gannosuke in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Luchas de Apuestas|hair vs. hair match]] at FMW's [[FMW 8th Anniversary Show|8th Anniversary Show]]. After the match, Hayabusa said that Gannosuke's hair would not be cut off if he left Funk Masters of Wrestling and side with FMW and Gannosuke apparently shook his hands and then attacked Hayabusa, thus removed his mask and attempted to blow fire on him until Jinsei Shinzaki made the save.{{cite web|url=http://www.puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-KudoRetirement.html|title=Megumi Kudo Retirement Show, 4/29/97 |publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-26|author=Stuart}} As a result, Hayabusa formed a [[tag team]] with Shinzaki. They teamed with each other for the first time by teaming with Koji Nakagawa against Funk Masters of Wrestling members Hisakatsu Oya, Mr. Gannosuke and The Gladiator in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Multiple man teamed matches|six-man tag team match]] on July 19.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45552|title=FMW King Of Fight II 1997 - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-27}} On August 5, Hayabusa teamed with Nakagawa and Ricky Fuji in a tournament for the vacant [[FMW World Street Fight 6-Man Tag Team Championship|World Street Fight 6-Man Tag Team Championship]]. They lost to eventual winners Oya, Gannosuke and Gladiator in the semi-final round.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=159482|title=Fuyuki Army results - August 5, 1997|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-27}} On August 31, the trio of Hayabusa, Nakagawa and Masato Tanaka defeated Oya, Gannosuke and Gladiator to win the World Street Fight 6-Man Tag Team Championship.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45569|title=FMW Super Dynamism 1997 - Tag 9 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-27}} On September 28, Hayabusa wrestled two matches on the same day. He first appeared in a tag team match for AJPW at [[Korakuen Hall]] in [[Tokyo]] by teaming with [[Mitsuharu Misawa]] to defeat [[Jun Akiyama]] and Saturo Asako.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=93616|title=AJPW October Giant Series 1997 - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}} He then travelled to [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa]] to compete at FMW's [[Fall Spectacular (1997)|Fall Spectacular]] at the [[Kawasaki Stadium]], where he and Shinzaki lost to AJPW's [[Kenta Kobashi]] and [[Taiyo Kea|Maunakea Mossman]] in a highly acclaimed tag team match.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/miscfmw.html#fall97|title=Fall Spectacular 1997 results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-27}} On October 14, Hayabusa, Nakagawa and Tanaka [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Drop|drop]]ped the six-man tag team title to [[ZEN (professional wrestling)|ZEN]] members Atsushi Onita, Hido and Tetsuhiro Kuroda.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45614|title=FMW Power Splash 1997 - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-27}} This marked the beginning of a feud between Hayabusa and Onita as Onita wanted to stay on the top of FMW while Ezaki wanted to remain the ace of the company. Hayabusa and Shinzaki participated in AJPW's [[World's Strongest Tag Determination League#1997|1997 Real World Tag League]] and kicked off the tournament on November 19 by defeating Giant Kimala and [[Jun Izumida]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=40922|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}} They finished the tournament with four points{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/alljapan/tag90.html#97|title=Real World Tag League 1997 Tournament Brackets|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-28}} as they would win only one more match against [[John Hindley|Johnny Smith]] and [[Jim Steele (wrestler)|Wolf Hawkfield]],{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=88192|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 13 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}} while losing the rest of their matches.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=40923|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=88185|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 4 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=40924|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 5 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=88186|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 7 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=88189|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 10 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=88191|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 12 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=88193|title=AJPW Real World Tag League 1997 - Tag 14 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}} Hayabusa and Masato Tanaka faced Mr. Gannosuke and [[Kouhiro Kanemura|Yukihiro Kanemura]] in a losing effort for the vacant [[FMW Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship|Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship]] on November 28.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45637|title=FMW Scramble Survivor 1997 - Tag 9 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-28}} Hayabusa and Jinsei Shinzaki unsuccessfully challenged Gannosuke and Kanemura for the tag team title on December 19.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45688|title=FMW Super Extreme Wrestling War 1997 - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-29}} On December 20, Hayabusa, Hisakatsu Oya and Masato Tanaka won the World Street Fight Six-Man Tag Team Championship by beating Atsushi Onita, Hido and Tetsuhiro Kuroda during the [[Super Extreme Wrestling War]] tour.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45689|title=FMW Super Extreme Wrestling War 1997 - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-29}} On December 22, Hayabusa, Jinsei Shinzaki and Masato Tanaka defeated ZEN members Atsushi Onita, Mr. Gannosuke and Yukihiro Kanemura in a [[WarGames match]] after Hayabusa pinned Onita after a [[Moonsault]] from the top of the cage as a payback for his loss to Onita at 6th Anniversary Show in 1995.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45693|title=FMW Super Extreme Wrestling War 1997 - Tag 4 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2018-02-09}} Hayabusa started getting [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Over|over]] with the audience and he was finally being heavily [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Push|push]]ed. Friction arose within ZEN and Gannosuke formed his own group [[Team No Respect]]. On January 16, 1998, Hayabusa, Masato Tanaka and Hisakatsu Oya lost their six-man tag team title to Team No Respect members Gannosuke, Yukihiro Kanemura and [[Jado (wrestler)|Jado]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45709|title=FMW New Year Generation - Tag 8 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-29}} Hayabusa and his allies battled Team No Respect members for the next three months{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/FMWEndofEra.html|title=FMW official results (5/8/97 - 4/30/98)|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-10-29}} and Hayabusa lost a singles match to TNR member [[Hiromichi Fuyuki|Kodo Fuyuki]] in the first singles encounter between the two on February 19 to begin a long lasting rivalry with Fuyuki.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45718|title=Fuyuki Army results - February 19, 1998|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-29}} The following month, Hayabusa won a tournament by defeating Masato Tanaka,{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45723|title=FMW Winning Road 1998 - Tag 5 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-29}} Jado{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45725|title=FMW Winning Road 1998 - Tag 7 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-29}} and The Gladiator{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45726|title=FMW Winning Road 1998 - Tag 8 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-29}} to become the #1 contender for his rival Mr. Gannosuke's FMW Double Championship, the [[Championship unification|unified]] Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship and the [[FMW Independent Heavyweight Championship|Independent Heavyweight Championship]]. On April 17, Hayabusa and Masato Tanaka defeated Hido and Kodo Fuyuki to win the Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45734|title=Fuyuki Army results - April 17, 1998|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-29}} On April 30, Hayabusa defeated Mr. Gannosuke to win the Double Titles Championship at FMW's first [[List of FMW supercards and pay-per-view events|pay-per-view]] [[FMW 9th Anniversary Show|9th Anniversary Show: Entertainment Wrestling Live]].{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-8.30.98.html|title=Entertainment Wrestling Live review|publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-29|author=Kevin Wilson}} Immediately after the title win, Hayabusa appeared at AJPW's twenty-fifth anniversary show Showdown at the Egg, where he teamed with AJPW owner Giant Baba and Kentaro Shiga against Jinsei Shinzaki, Jun Izumida and Giant Kimala. Hayabusa got the win for his team by pinning Izumida.{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/AJReview-TokyoDome98.html|title=All Japan Tokyo Dome Show 1998 review|publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-29|author=Kevin Wilson}} Hayabusa made his first title defense of the Double Championship against his tag team championship partner Masato Tanaka on May 19, where Hayabusa retained the title.{{cite web|url=http://www.puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-StoryF3BestRyan.html|title=FMW Story of the F Stage 3 review|publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-29|author=Kevin Wilson}}{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1998fmwppv.html#598|title=FMW PPV results - May 19, 1998|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-30}} The match between the two earned critical acclaim and is highly regarded as the best match of Ezaki's career. On May 27, Hayabusa and Tanaka lost the Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship to Kodo Fuyuki and Yukihiro Kanemura.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45819|title=FMW Neo 1998 - Tag 7 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-30}} Shortly after, Tanaka left FMW and Ezaki made [[Daisuke Ikeda]] his new tag team partner. During this time, Gannosuke was injured and Kodo Fuyuki became the new leader of Team No Respect. Hayabusa and his allies split wins with Team No Respect at the June and July pay-per-views.{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-6.19.98.html|title=FMW June 19, 1998 PPV review|publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-31|author=Stuart}}{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1998fmwppv.html#798|title=FMW July 1998 pay-per-view results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-31}} On August 2, Hayabusa made an appearance for [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]] (ECW) at the [[Heat Wave (1998)|Heat Wave]] [[List of ECW supercards and pay-per-view events|pay-per-view]] where he and Jinsei Shinzaki unsuccessfully challenged [[Rob Van Dam and Sabu]] for the [[ECW World Tag Team Championship]].{{cite web|url=https://411mania.com/wrestling/random-network-reviews-ecw-heatwave-1998/|title=Heat Wave 1998 review|publisher=411mania|accessdate=2017-10-31|date=December 11, 2014|author=Kevin Pantoja}} Hayabusa returned to FMW to begin a feud with Koji Nakagawa after Nakagawa pinned him to win an [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Elimination tag team matches|elimination tag team match]]. As a result, Hayabusa faced him as "Darkside Hayabusa" in a losing effort at the [[Welcome to the Darkside]] pay-per-view.{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-8.22.98.html|title=FMW August 22, 1998 PPV review|publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-31|author=Stuart}} On September 1, Hayabusa successfully defended the Double Championship in his third defense against Hisakatsu Oya{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45855|title=FMW Super Dynamism 1998 - Tag 8 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-31}} after the duo wrestled to a thirty-minute time limit draw.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45844|title=FMW Heaven - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-31}} He made his next title defense against Jado on September 20, where he retained and then teamed with Ricky Fuji to take on Kodo Fuyuki, Koji Nakagawa and [[Gedo (wrestler)|Gedo]] in an [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Impromptu match|immediate]] [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match|handicap match]], which he lost and this earned Nakagawa and Fuyuki title shots at the Double Championship.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45860|title=Fuyuki Army results - September 20, 1998|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-31}} Ezaki successfully defended the title against Nakagawa at the October pay-per-view.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1998fmwppv.html#1098|title=FMW PPV results - October 6, 1998|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-10-31}} On October 26, Hayabusa and Ikeda defeated Kodo Fuyuki and Yukihiro Kanemura to capture the Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45876|title=Fuyuki Army results - October 26, 1998|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-31}} They made only one title defense against [[Hideki Hosaka]] and Tetsuhiro Kuroda on November 14.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=17260|title=Battlarts results - November 14, 1998|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-10-31}} On November 20, Hayabusa lost the Double Championship to Fuyuki in his sixth title defense.{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-11.20.98.html|title=FMW November 20, 1998 PPV review|publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2017-10-31|author=Stuart}} Hayabusa participated in an Over the Top tournament to earn a title shot at the Double Championship by defeating Gedo in the first round, before losing to Hisakatsu Oya in the quarter-final round at the [[ECW/FMW Supershow#ECW/FMW Supershow II|ECW/FMW Supershow II]].{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1998fmwppv.html#1298|title=ECW/FMW Supershow II results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-01}} ====All Asia Tag Team Champion (1999)==== In early 1999, Hayabusa and Daisuke Ikeda vacated the Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship after Ikeda suffered an injury. On January 16, 1999, Hayabusa reunited with [[Jinsei Shinzaki]] at an [[All Japan Pro Wrestling|AJPW]] show to challenge [[Tamon Honda]] and [[Jun Izumida]] for the [[All Asia Tag Team Championship]] in a losing effort.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=5005|title=AJPW New Year Giant Series 1999 - Tag 12 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}} Hayabusa and Shinzaki were granted a rematch on February 13, in which they defeated Honda and Izumida to capture the All Asia Tag Team Championship.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=5710|title=AJPW Fan Appreciation Day results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}} Hayabusa and Shinzaki made their first and only successful title defense against Masato Tanaka and [[Tetsuhiro Kuroda]] on March 19.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=38894|title=FMW PPV results - March 19, 1999|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}} Hayabusa renewed his rivalry with Mr. Gannosuke and formed an alliance with rival Double Champion Kodo Fuyuki. Hayabusa and Fuyuki entered a [[round robin tournament]] for the vacant Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship, where they qualified for the finals by topping the tournament with thirteen points{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/fmwtny.html#brasstag99|title=FMW Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship League 1999 Brackets|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-01}} by winning all of their matches{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45997|title=FMW Round Robin Tag League - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=45998|title=FMW Round Robin Tag League - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}}{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1999fmwppv.html#499|title=FMW PPV results - April 20, 1999|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-01}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46007|title=FMW Strongest Tag League - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46008|title=FMW Strongest Tag League - Tag 3 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46010|title=FMW Strongest Tag League - Tag 4 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}} except fighting Masato Tanaka and Tetsuhiro Kuroda to a thirty-minute time limit draw on March 29.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1999fmwppv.html#399|title=FMW PPV results - March 29, 1999|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-01}} On May 3, Hayabusa and Fuyuki lost to Tanaka and Kuroda in the final round.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46012|title=FMW Strongest Tag League - Tag 6 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}} After the match, Hayabusa poured water on Fuyuki to revive him which angered Fuyuki and the two came to blows and this ended the partnership between the two. On May 5, Hayabusa and Shinzaki took on Tanaka and Kuroda in a tag team match where the winner of the fall would earn a Double Championship match against Kodo Fuyuki in the main event and Kuroda pinned Hayabusa to earn the title shot.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1999fmwppv.html#599|title=FMW PPV results - May 5, 1999|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-01}} Fuyuki took over as the new [[Professional wrestling authority figures|commissioner]] of FMW and an alliance was formed between Gannosuke's Outlaws and Team No Respect. On May 31, Hayabusa, Masato Tanaka, Tetsuhiro Kuroda, Hideki Hosaka and Hisakatsu Oya faced Kodo Fuyuki, Mr. Gannosuke, Hido, Koji Nakagawa and Yukihiro Kanemura in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Elimination tag team matches|five-on-five elimination tag team match]] which Hayabusa's FMW team won with a clean sweep as his entire team survived.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46019|title=FMW results - May 31, 1999|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-01}} On June 4, Hayabusa and Shinzaki lost the All Asia Tag Team Championship to [[No Fear (professional wrestling)|No Fear]] ([[Takao Omori]] and [[Yoshihiro Takayama]]). ====Character change (1999–2000)==== {{See also|Goodbye Hayabusa}} Ezaki had suffered multiple injuries during the past few years of his career which forced him to change his wrestling style from high flying to mat wrestling. This was incorporated into a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Angle|storyline]] that Kodo Fuyuki would not allow Ezaki to wear the falcon mask and compete as Hayabusa anymore. This led Ezaki to go through a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick|character]] change. On June 15, Hayabusa teamed with Masato Tanaka and Tetsuhiro Kuroda to defeat Mr. Gannosuke, Yukihiro Kanemura and Hido in a [[ladder match]] which stipulated that Fuyuki had to eat [[dog food]] if his team lost.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1999fmwppv.html#699|title=FMW PPV results - June 15, 1999|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-03}} FMW held a series of events titled ''Goodbye Hayabusa'' as a farewell to Ezaki's Hayabusa character. During this time, he participated in a tournament with Tanaka and Kuroda for the newly created [[WEW 6-Man Tag Team Championship]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46025|title=FMW Goodbye Hayabusa - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-03}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46026|title=FMW Goodbye Hayabusa - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-03}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46030|title=FMW Goodbye Hayabusa - Tag 6 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-03}} Hayabusa and his team reached the finals of the tournament on [[Goodbye Hayabusa#July 31 pay-per-view|July 31]], where they lost to Kodo Fuyuki, Gedo and Koji Nakagawa.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1999fmwppv.html#799|title=FMW PPV results - July 31, 1999|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-03}} At [[Goodbye Hayabusa II: Hayabusa Graduation Ceremony|Hayabusa Graduation Ceremony]], Hayabusa defeated Yukihiro Kanemura to win his third [[FMW Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship|Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship]]{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46034|title=FMW Goodbye Hayabusa II - Hayabusa Graduation Ceremony results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-03}} and made his first and only title defense against Mr. Gannosuke on August 25 in his [[Goodbye Hayabusa II: Last Match|last match]] as Hayabusa, which he won to retain the title.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46035|title=FMW Goodbye Hayabusa II - Last Match results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-03}} The title was immediately retired. On August 27, Ezaki debuted his new character '''H''', with a complete makeover of colored hair, a tattooed chest and [[jeans]]. Ezaki won his first match as H, an elimination match against Team No Respect.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46039|title=FMW Making Of A New Legend II - Tag 4 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-03}} Gannosuke was injured in the match and then he attacked H under the Hayabusa costume and attire on September 3, thus instigating a feud between H and Hayabusa. This led to an [[Hardcore wrestling|anus exploding match]] between the two on October 29, which ended in a no contest.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/1999fmwppv.html#1099|title=FMW PPV results - October 29, 1999|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-04}} At the [[FMW 10th Anniversary Show|10th Anniversary Show]], H defeated fake Hayabusa in the main event, with [[Shawn Michaels]] as the special guest referee.{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-11.23.99.html|title=FMW Review - November 23rd, 1999|publisher=Puroresu Central|author=Stuart|accessdate=2017-11-12}} H and Gannosuke reconciled after the match by shaking hands with each other to end their rivalry and form a tag team. On December 1, H and Gannosuke defeated Tetsuhiro Kuroda and [[Hisakatsu Oya]] to win the [[WEW Tag Team Championship]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46074|title=FMW Making Of A New Legend VI - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-04}} H and Gannosuke lost the title to Kodo Fuyuki and [[Kyoko Inoue]] on February 25, 2000.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#0200|title=FMW PPV results - February 25, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-06}} H defeated Inoue in singles action on March 27.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#0300|title=FMW PPV results - March 27, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-06}} On April 3, H represented FMW against the new ECW Japan leader Kodo Fuyuki in a losing effort.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46095|title=FMW Winning Road 2000 - Tag 5 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-04}} H began feuding with [[Masato Tanaka]] due to Tanaka confronting him on forgiving Mr. Gannosuke. Ezaki and Gannosuke lost to Tanaka and [[Balls Mahoney]] in a tag team match on April 11, during which Ezaki went backstage as H and then competed as Hayabusa for the first time in several months.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#0400|title=FMW PPV results - April 11, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-06}} Ezaki's H character had failed to garner [[Over (professional wrestling)|crowd support]] and ticket sales were dwindling, which caused Ezaki to slowly transition back to compete as Hayabusa. At [[FMW 11th Anniversary Show|Backdraft]], he competed as Hayabusa in a win over Tanaka.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46110|title=FMW Golden Series 2000 - Tag 8: Backdraft results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-06}} On May 28, H competed against Gannosuke and Tetsuhiro Kuroda in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches|three-way dance]] to determine the #1 contender for the [[WEW Heavyweight Championship]] with the champion Kodo Fuyuki as the special guest referee. H eliminated Kuroda and then Gannosuke turned on H by hitting with a crutch and pinned him with Fuyuki's help and became a member of Shin Fuyuki-Gun.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46112|title=FMW Neo 2000 - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On June 16, Ezaki unleashed Darkside of H and brought "[[Genichiro Tenryu|Hayabusa]]" as his tag team partner for a match against [[Koji Nakagawa|GOEMON]] and Kodo Fuyuki. H and Hayabusa won the match to take revenge from Shin-Fuyuki-Gun for attacking and kidnapping Ricky Fuji.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#0600|title=FMW PPV results - June 16, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On June 26, H won the [[WEW 6-Man Tag Team Championship]] with Hisakatsu Oya and Tetsuhiro Kuroda by defeating Kodo Fuyuki, Kyoko Inoue and [[Chocoball Mukai]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46131|title=FMW King Of Fight II 2000 - Tag 5 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On July 22, Ezaki retired his H character and announced that he would begin competing as Hayabusa again after he and Tetsuhiro Kuroda defeated [[3-Minute Warning|The Samoans]] ([[Umaga (wrestler)|Eddie Fatu]] and [[Rosey (wrestler)|Matty Samu]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46141|title=FMW King Of Fight II 2000 - Tag 7 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} ====WEW Heavyweight Champion and career-ending injury (2000–2001)==== On July 23, Ezaki revived his Hayabusa character after a year and defeated Shin Fuyuki-Gun members in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Gauntlet match|gauntlet match]] to earn an immediate [[WEW Heavyweight Championship]] match against Kodo Fuyuki, which he lost after Jinsei Shinzaki turned on Hayabusa.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46142|title=FMW King Of Fight II 2000 - Tag 8 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On July 28, Hayabusa, Masato Tanaka and Hisakatsu Oya defeated Fuyuki, Shinzaki and [[Mr. Gannosuke]] after Hayabusa pinned Gannosuke.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#0700|title=FMW PPV results - July 28, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} This set up a match against Gannosuke on August 28, which Hayabusa won to earn a shot at Fuyuki's WEW Heavyweight Championship.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#0800|title=FMW PPV results - August 28, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On September 15, Hayabusa, Hisakatsu Oya and Tetsuhiro Kuroda lost the WEW 6-Man Tag Team Championship to Fuyuki, Gannosuke and Shinjuku Shark.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46152|title=FMW Flashover 2000 - Tag 4 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On September 21, Hayabusa defeated Fuyuki in a non-title [[Hardcore wrestling#Rules|15,000 volt thunderbolt cage death match]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46154|title=FMW Flashover 2000 - Tag 7 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On September 26, Hayabusa took on Fuyuki for the WEW Heavyweight Championship in a sixty-minute [[Iron Man match]], which ended in a draw.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#0900|title=FMW PPV results - September 26, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} Hayabusa called it the hardest match of his career. After the match, Hayabusa demanded another title shot, which Fuyuki agreed. On October 29, Hayabusa and [[Onryo (wrestler)|Onryo]] defeated GOEMON and Fuyuki in a tag team match.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#1000|title=FMW PPV results - October 29, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On November 12, Hayabusa got another title shot against Fuyuki at the [[FMW Deep Throat|Deep Throat]] pay-per-view, but lost the match.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2000fmwppv.html#1100-1|title=FMW PPV results - November 12, 2000|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} Hayabusa and Fuyuki ended the feud after the match by shaking hands with each other and then Tetsuhiro Kuroda turned on Hayabusa by attacking him. Hayabusa then took time off to heal his injured arms. Hayabusa had a successful double elbow surgery on November 22. He returned to FMW at a pay-per-view on December 20 as a color commentator, along with Mr. Gannosuke, who had retired from wrestling after losing to Tetsuhiro Kuroda. During the match, Kuroda mocked Hayabusa to anger him and Hayabusa headed to the ring but Gannosuke held him back. On February 6, 2001, Hayabusa made another non-wrestling appearance to confront Kuroda along with The Masked Sumo. Sumo turned on Gannosuke and Kuroda injured Hayabusa's arms with a folding chair until [[The Great Sasuke]] made the save. On April 1, Hayabusa appeared during Kuroda and Kodo Fuyuki's WEW Heavyweight Championship match, where he attacked Mr. Gannosuke after Gannosuke attacked Fuyuki during the match and then Kuroda and his allies attacked Hayabusa until Sasuke came to his rescue again. Hayabusa made his in-ring return at the [[FMW 12th Anniversary Show|12th Anniversary Show]] on May 5 by teaming with Sasuke to defeat Kuroda and Gannosuke in an [[Hardcore wrestling|octagon cage electric bomb death match]].{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2001fmwppv.html#501-1|title=Kawasaki Legend 2001 results|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} This match also commemorated the tenth anniversary of his FMW debut.{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/Hayabusa3.html|title=Hayabusa's Biography: Part 3|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On May 11, Hayabusa pinned Kuroda in a six-man tag team match to earn a title shot at Kuroda.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46362|title=FMW Neo 2001 - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On May 22, Hayabusa defeated Kuroda in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Barbed Wire Massacre|double hell barbed wire]] [[Hardcore wrestling#Rules|deathmatch]] to win the WEW Heavyweight Championship, with Kodo Fuyuki as the special guest referee.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46364|title=FMW Neo 2001 - Tag 2 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On June 8, Fuyuki bought FMW from [[Shoichi Arai]] [[kayfabe|in storyline]] and gave the wrestlers option to either side with Arai or Fuyuki. Hayabusa sided with Arai by revealing that he had purchased 5% stock of the company. Tetsuhiro Kuroda also refused to side with Fuyuki and this resulted in Hayabusa and Kuroda being paired to take on Mr. Gannosuke and [[Kouhiro Kanemura|Kintaro Kanemura]] in a tag team match, which they lost.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2001fmwppv.html#601|title=FMW PPV results - June 8, 2001|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} Hayabusa made his first title defense of the WEW Heavyweight Championship against [[Mammoth Sasaki]] on July 30, where he retained the title.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46401|title=FMW Super Dynamism 2001 - Tag 1 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On August 3, Hayabusa offered to put his 5% stock if he, GOEMON and Onryo lost the six-man tag team match to Mr. Gannosuke, Kintaro Kanemura and Mammoth Sasaki. Hayabusa was pinned by Kanemura and he agreed to put his 5% stock in a two out of three match series on August 11.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2001fmwppv.html#801-1|title=FMW PPV results - August 3, 2001|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} The FMW team and Fuyuki's team were even with 1-1 score until Hayabusa lost the WEW Heavyweight Championship to Kanemura in the main event.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2001fmwppv.html#801-2|title=FMW PPV results - August 11, 2001|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} As a result of losing the series, Hayabusa lost his 5% stock to Fuyuki and Fuyuki sold the stock to Stuart Levy. On September 5, Hayabusa defeated Kanemura to regain the title but the win was reversed by new FMW Vice President Senmu Yoshida, who returned the title to Kanemura.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=46401|title=FMW Super Dynamism 2001 - Tag 13 results|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=2017-11-07}} On September 9, Hayabusa teamed with Tetsuhiro Kuroda and GOEMON to defeat Kintaro Kanemura, Kodo Fuyuki and Mr. Gannosuke to win the WEW 6-Man Tag Team Championship.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2001fmwppv.html#901-1|title=FMW PPV results - September 9, 2001|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} The following month, on October 9, Hayabusa and Kuroda defeated Gannosuke and Mammoth Sasaki to win the [[WEW Tag Team Championship]].{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2001fmwppv.html#1001-1|title=FMW PPV results - October 9, 2001|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}} After the match, Sasaki challenged Hayabusa to a match which stipulated that if Hayabusa won then Shoichi Arai would be reinstated as FMW President. The match took place on October 22, during which Hayabusa suffered a career-ending injury when he attempted a [[Moonsault#Springboard moonsault|springboard moonsault]] off the middle rope and lost footing, landing on his head, cracking two of his vertebrae and leaving him paralyzed.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/garbage/fmw/2001fmwppv.html#1001-2|title=FMW PPV results - October 22, 2001|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|accessdate=2017-11-07}}{{cite news|title=Wrestler's Paralysis May Raise Some Doubts In Jericho|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2001-10-26/entertainment/0110241266_1_most-dangerous-performer-wwf-chris-jericho|accessdate=2018-01-01|date=October 26, 2001|author=Alex Marvez}} The injury provoked a high fever and required surgery. This injury ended his wrestling career. As he was considered the heart and soul of FMW, the company slowly folded after his departure. ==Post-retirement== Ezaki later pursued a career as a singer. He promoted a new wrestling company called WMF (Wrestlings Marvelous Future) that contained up-and-coming wrestlers. The name was chosen since, spelled backwards, the initials are FMW in honor of the late company. He traveled to a few [[WWE]] events where he met old friends such as Sabu, [[Rob Van Dam]], and [[Rey Mysterio, Jr.|Rey Mysterio]] backstage. He also took photographs with [[Vince McMahon]], [[Shane McMahon]], and [[Triple H]], and spoke with [[Jeff Hardy]]. Ezaki attended the PWU (Pro Wrestling Unplugged) FAHRENHEIT: 3RD DEGREE event on August 19, 2006, at the New Alhambra (formerly known as ECW Arena). This was his first appearance in the USA since 2000, the last time being at [[E3 (Electronic Entertainment Expo)|E3]] in Los Angeles, helping promote [[TOKYOPOP]]'s FMW DVDs by having a 6-man tag match. He also participated in a shoot interview with RF Video. Ezaki was active in working with the [[Dragon Gate]] promotion. He recorded a debut album with [[Dragon Kid]] titled ''Trust!''{{cite web|url=http://spora.jp/hayabusa_dragonkid/ |title=ドラゴン・キッドオフィシャルブログ「Trust!」powered by SPORA |publisher=Spora.jp |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04}} which came out in November 2007. He partook in the company's first US tour, joining them in their appearance in Los Angeles on September 5 and Hawaii on September 8, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://a319.ac-images.myspacecdn.com/images01/67/l_49758bcc5ce0b5d4b21ec1d0e1637556.jpg|title=Image: l_49758bcc5ce0b5d4b21ec1d0e1637556.jpg|publisher=a319.ac-images.myspacecdn.com|accessdate=2015-09-02}} Ezaki also designed the tour's T-shirt.{{cite web|url=http://a269.ac-images.myspacecdn.com/images01/12/l_1ad541f6b70f22747442fdde63f3fb74.jpg|title=Image: l_1ad541f6b70f22747442fdde63f3fb74.jpg|publisher=a269.ac-images.myspacecdn.com|accessdate=2015-09-02}} When asked about his career in an interview, Ezaki said that one never knows what the chances are of a return to the ring. On 3 April 2015, Hayabusa was part of a press conference announcing the return of FMW. He served as the executive producer of the promotion.{{cite web|url=http://www.daily.co.jp/newsflash/ring/2015/04/03/0007881138.shtml|title=ＦＭＷ復活　ハヤブサ復帰リングを用意|date=2015-04-03|accessdate=2015-04-03|work=Daily Sports Online|language=Japanese}} ==Legacy== Ezaki was considered to be one of the greatest professional wrestlers in the history of professional wrestling and one of the pioneers of high-flying and [[Cruiserweight (professional wrestling)|junior heavyweight wrestling]] in Japan. He was the innovator of ''[[Suplex#Sitout suplex slam|Falcon Arrow]]'' and ''[[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Corkscrew 450° splash|Phoenix Splash]]'' and also popularized the ''[[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#450° splash|Firebird Splash]]'', which would become famous in North America as the [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#450° splash|450° splash]]. He was the most popular and greatest star in the history of [[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling]], where he spent the entirety of his career. Due to his impressive talent, Ezaki received offers with better salaries from [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] and [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]], which could have driven him to success but he rejected all those offers out of loyalty to FMW. He worked hard as the company's [[Franchise player|ace]], even putting his body on the line and worked in some of the greatest matches in the company's history. His match with [[Masato Tanaka]] on May 19, 1998, was considered by many to be the greatest match of his career and considered to be the second best FMW match only behind [[Noriyo Toyoda|Combat Toyoda]] vs. [[Megumi Kudo]] at [[FMW 7th Anniversary Show|7th Anniversary Show]].{{cite web|url=http://fmwwrestling.us/FMW100.html|title=Top 100 FMW Matches|publisher=[[Frontier Martial-Arts Wrestling|FMW Wrestling]]|accessdate=2018-01-01}} He had memorable rivalries and clashes with [[Mr. Gannosuke]], [[Hiromichi Fuyuki|Kodo Fuyuki]] and [[Mike Awesome|The Gladiator]]. His feud with Gannosuke would feature both men in many epic encounters and major matches between 1997 and 2001 and was considered the biggest feud in FMW history. They headlined many shows including [[FMW 8th Anniversary Show|8th Anniversary Show]], [[FMW 9th Anniversary Show|9th Anniversary Show]] and [[FMW 10th Anniversary Show|10th Anniversary Show]] as well as the [[Card (sports)#Main event|main event]] of [[Goodbye Hayabusa II: Last Match]] pay-per-view which was the last match of the Hayabusa character in 1999. Kevin Wilson reviewed on the 9th Anniversary Show encounter between the two that "both wrestlers played their roles well and they hit their major moves without any problems. I still think the Phoenix Splash is one of the top five most beautiful moves in wrestling (let's see... Phoenix Splash, Shooting Star Press, Space Flying Tiger Drop, Ultimo Dragon's Asai Moonsault, and a Dragonrana), and Hayabusa hit it perfectly. It was the perfect ending, as the two other times he had gone for the move in the match he had failed... he knew that to win the titles he had to hit his ultimate finisher. Overall a really fun match, it wasn't perfectly executed, but the good far outweighed the bad." Stuart of Puroresu Central stated that "Hayabusa's highspots were dazzling as always and Gannosuke's craftsmanship made them look better and very important. They fought almost one year exactly before this and Hayabusa smoked Gannosuke as a worker" and considered it "a worthy main event between two excellent wrestlers and undoubtedly the best match on the show."{{cite web|url=http://puroresucentral.com/FMWReview-8.30.98Stu.html|author=Stuart|title=FMW DirecTV PPV, 4/30/98|publisher=Puroresu Central|accessdate=2018-01-01}} Many of the industry's wrestlers like [[Chris Jericho]], [[Jack Evans (wrestler)|Jack Evans]],{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2003/12/11/284336.html|title=Jack Evans soars on indy scene|date=December 11, 2003|last=Clevett|first=Jason|accessdate=2018-01-28|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}} [[Neville (wrestler)|Neville]] and [[Kalisto (wrestler)|Kalisto]] were inspired by Hayabusa at some point in their careers.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagesideseats.com/2016/3/5/11165950/wwe-njpw-sami-zayn-finn-balor-neville-more-tweet-memories-hayabusa|title=WWE, Chris Jerico, AJ Styles and more pay tribute to Hayabusa|date=March 5, 2016|author=Sean Rueter|work=Cageside Seats}} ==Other media== *As a musician, Hayabusa has released three solo albums (one posthumously), an album with [[Dragon Kid]], and an album with [[Koji Nakagawa]] and Masahiko. *Hayabusa appears in the low-budget wrestling movie ''Backyard Dogs'' and in ''Mask de 41'' as the "Red Falcon". He also appears as Eiji Ezaki in ''Baion''. *Hayabusa also appeared in the music video "Life Is...~another story~" by J-Pop artist [[Ken Hirai]]. *Hayabusa appears in the Japan-exclusive [[Nintendo 64]] games ''[[Virtual Pro Wrestling 64]]'' and ''[[Virtual Pro Wrestling 2: Ōdō Keishō]]''. He appears unofficially in ''[[WCW vs. nWo: World Tour]]'', as Hannibal, in ''[[WCW/nWo Revenge]]'', as Han Zo Mon, and in ''[[WCW vs. the World]]'' as Habanero. ==Personal life== Ezaki was the oldest of two sons. His grandparents on his mother's side of the family were owners of a hotel, before his parents took over. Ezaki married his wife Harumi on April 7, 1997. Together, they had two daughters, Ayane (born October 19, 1997) and Shie (born May 10, 1999). He and Harumi amicably divorced in 2004, but remained friends, while sharing custody of their daughters. Ezaki was close friends with [[Jyushin Thunder Liger]] since 1994. The two had a falling out in 1996 after Ezaki turned down a deal with [[NJPW]], but they mended their friendship in 2005. In May 2005, he performed a play called The Shinichi Amano Story at the Tokyo Shinjuku Theater. He portrayed the main character's best friend Fuyuki Hayato, an injured air pilot soldier in World War II, who is wheelchair-bound. His performance was given positive reviews and the play was a huge success. On April 25, 2010, his father died. By 2015, Ezaki had regained the use of his legs and could stand on his own and walk with a cane.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Other_News_4/article_84265.shtml|title=Japan news: 1990s FMW promotion looking to make a comeback|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2015-04-03|accessdate=2015-04-03|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}} ==Death== Ezaki died of a [[cerebral hemorrhage]] on March 3, 2016 at age 47.{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/mexico/fmw-star-hayabusa-passed-away-thursday-208701|title=FMW star Hayabusa passed away at 47|last=Meltzer|first=Dave|authorlink=Dave Meltzer|date=2016-03-03|accessdate=2016-03-04|work=[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]}} His body was found when the owner of a nearby tavern, with whom he was scheduled to meet concerning a March 7 event, went to his home after Ezaki failed to arrive for their planned meeting.{{cite web|url=http://www.tokyo-sports.co.jp/prores/mens_prores/514263/|title=ハヤブサさん「急死の詳細」を関係者明かす|date=2016-03-04|accessdate=2016-03-04|work=[[Tokyo Sports]]|language=Japanese}} ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''Florida Wrestling Alliance''' **FWA Light Heavyweight Championship (1 time) *'''[[Frontier Martial Arts Wrestling]]''' **[[All Asia Tag Team Championship]] ([[All Asia Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) – with [[Jinsei Shinzaki]] **[[FMW Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship]] ([[FMW Brass Knuckles Heavyweight Championship#Title History|3 times, final]]) **[[FMW Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship]] ([[FMW Brass Knuckles Tag Team Championship#Title History|2 times]]) – with [[Masato Tanaka]] (1), [[Daisuke Ikeda]] (1) **[[FMW Independent Heavyweight Championship]] ([[FMW Independent Heavyweight Championship#Title History|1 time]]) **[[FMW World Street Fight 6-Man Tag Team Championship]] ([[FMW World Street Fight 6-Man Tag Team Championship#Title history|2 times]]) – with Masato Tanaka and [[Koji Nakagawa]] (1), and Masato Tanaka and [[Hisakatsu Oya]] (1) **[[WEW 6-Man Tag Team Championship]] ([[WEW 6-Man Tag Team Championship#Title history|2 times]]) – with [[Tetsuhiro Kuroda]] and Hisakatsu Oya (1), and Tetsuhiro Kuroda and GOEMON (1) **[[WEW Heavyweight Championship]] ([[WEW Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 times]]) **[[WEW Tag Team Championship]] ([[WEW Tag Team Championship#Title history|2 times]]) – with Mr. Gannosuke (1), Tetsuhiro Kuroda (1) **[[FMW tournaments#FMW Double Championship #1 Contender's Tournament|FMW Double Championship #1 Contender's Tournament (1998)]] *'''Plant City Wrestling Federation''' **PCWF Florida Heavyweight Championship (1 time) *'''''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''''' **PWI ranked him #'''38''' of the 500 best singles wrestlers in the [[Pro Wrestling Illustrated|PWI 500]] in 1998/1999{{cite web|url=http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=547&view=awards#awards|title=Hayabusa « Wrestlers Database « CAGEMATCH - The Internet Wrestling Database|publisher=cagematch.net|accessdate=2015-09-02}} **PWI ranked him #'''255''' of the 500 best singles wrestlers during the "PWI Years" in 2003 *'''''[[Tokyo Sports]]''''' **[[Tokyo Sports Puroresu Awards#Fighting Spirit Award|Fighting Spirit Award]] (1997){{cite web |url=http://www.purolove.com/tokyosports.php |title=Purolove.Com |publisher=Purolove.Com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016020657/http://www.purolove.com/tokyosports.php |archivedate=2012-10-16 |df= }} **[[Tokyo Sports Puroresu Awards#Service Award|Service Award]] (2016){{cite web|url=http://www.tokyo-sports.co.jp/prores/mens_prores/628622/|script-title=ja:【プロレス大賞】内藤哲也がＭＶＰ初受賞！　ベストバウトはＧ１丸藤ｖｓオカダ|date=2016-12-14|accessdate=2016-12-14|work=[[Tokyo Sports]]|language=Japanese}} revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name= '''Hla Thaung'''
{{my|လှသောင်း}} |parents' name= U Than Maung + Daw Saw Khin |birth_date= |death_date= 28 April 1949 |birth_place= Magyidan Quarter, [[Kungyangon Township]], [[Rangoon Division]], [[British Burma]] |death_place= [[Daik-U Township|Daik-U]], [[Bago Division|Pegu Division]], [[Myanmar|Burma]] |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= [[Union of Burma]] |branch= Myanmar Army |serviceyears= 1947-1949 |rank= [[Private (rank)|Private]] |commands= |unit=3rd Burma Rifles Battalion |battles= Rakhine Yoma
Irrawaddy delta
Battle of Insein
Battle of Daik-U |awards= [[Aung San Thuriya]] |laterwork= }} '''[[Private (rank)|Private]] ''[[Aung San Thuriya]]'' Hla Thaung''' ({{lang-my|လှသောင်း}} {{IPA-my|l̥a̰ θáʊɴ|}}; died 28 April 1949) of [[3rd Burma Rifles]] Battalion (Bama Thenatkaing Tatyin - Tha Na Ka) (Serial 88865) was a recipient of [[Aung San Thuriya]] Award, the highest and most prestigious award in [[Myanmar]] (Burma) for gallantry and bravery in the face of the enemy. He won the award at the [[Battle of Daik-U]] during the fight against of Karen insurgency in Myanmar. On the early hours on 28 April 1949 at the Daik-U battlefront, HQ company of 3rd Burma Rifles [[Battalion]] was encircled by the attacking [[KNDO]] forces with much greater strength supported by artillery. Private Hla Thaung gallantly fought back the insurgents to defend the HQ company. He fought with bravery and risk his life while killing large numbers of enemy troops and halting the enemy advances towards the position of HQ Company. Holding a Bren GPMG Gun in his hand, firing non-stop to hold off the enemy until his last dying breath, Private Hla Thaung provided covering fire for the troops of 3rd Burma Rifles Battalion to retreat safely from the encircled position. He fell during this battle and when his comrades found his body after the battle, his fingers were still tightly gripped to the trigger of his Bren Gun. He was awarded Aung San Thuriya medal (Order No. 10/A Htoo/50) for his selfless valour, sacrificing his life in order to save the lives of his comrades and bravery in face of superior number of enemy forces.Defence Museum, Yangon Before the battle of Daik-U, Private Hla Thaung fought bravely against the insurgents in the battles of Rakhine Yoma, Irrawaddy Delta Region, Zeegon, Wetkaw and Insein. == Family == Hla Thaung was born to U Than Maung and his wife, Daw Than Khin, in Kungyangon, Ragoon Division, British Burma in 1929. His grandparents were subordinates of the [[Konbaung dynasty|Royal House of Konbaung]]. His grandfather, Pabe Wun U Shwe Bin, who along with [[Aung San]]'s grandfather Bo Min Yaung fought against the British annexation of Burma in 1886.{{Cite web|url=https://www.akhamaet.net/archives/8237|title=ေအာင္ဆန္းသူရိယ လွေသာင္း – အခမဲ႔|website=www.akhamaet.net|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-19}} == Commemorations == * [[Aung San Thuriya Hla Thaung High School]] in [[Mingaladon Township|Mingaladon]] is named in his honour. == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hla Thaung}} [[Category:Burmese soldiers]] [[Category:Military personnel killed in action]] [[Category:1949 deaths]] [[Category:People from Yangon Region]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Orders, decorations, and medals of Myanmar]] {{Myanmar-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Institute for Complex Adaptive Matter''' (ICAM) is an international multicampus collective of scientists studying [[emergent phenomena]] in biology, chemistry and physics and in wider context. ICAM was founded in 1999 at the [[University of California]] by Nobel laureate [[Robert B. Laughlin]] and physicist [[David Pines]] and since 2004 has received funding from the [[National Science Foundation]].
==External links== * [http://icam-i2cam.org/ ICAM-I2CAM web site]
[[Category:University of California]] [[Category:Emergence]]
{{sci-org-stub}}
