{{other people}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Mary | succession = [[Dukes of Brabant|Duchess of Brabant]], [[Dukes of Limburg|Limburg]], [[Dukes of Lothier|Lothier]],
[[Counts, Dukes and Grand Dukes of Luxembourg|Luxemburg]] and [[Dukes of Guelders|Guelders]]; [[Marquis of Namur|Margravine of Namur]]; [[List of counts of Burgundy|Countess Palatine of Burgundy]]; [[Counts of Artois|Countess of Artois]], [[Counts of Flanders|Flanders]], [[Charolais (county)|Charolais]], [[Counts of Hainaut|Hainaut]], [[Count of Holland|Holland]], [[Count of Zeeland|Zeeland]] and [[Count of Zutphen|Zutphen]] | image = Mary of burgundy pocher.jpg | caption = Portrait, accredited to [[Michael Pacher]], {{circa|1490}} | reign = 5 January 1477–27 March 1482 | coronation = | predecessor = [[Charles the Bold]] | successor = [[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor]]|1477}} | issue = [[Philip I of Castile]]
[[Archduchess Margaret of Austria|Margaret, Duchess of Savoy]] | house = [[House of Valois-Burgundy|Valois-Burgundy]] | father = [[Charles the Bold]] | mother = [[Isabella of Bourbon]] | birth_date = 13 February 1457 | birth_place = [[Brussels]], [[Duchy of Brabant|Brabant]], [[Burgundian Netherlands]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1482|3|27|1457|2|13|df=y}} | death_place = [[Wijnendale Castle]], [[County of Flanders|Flanders]], Burgundian Netherlands | burial_place = Bruges, Flanders | religion = [[Roman Catholicism]] }} [[File:Emanuel van Meteren Historie ppn 051504510 MG 8649 Maria van Valoys.tif|thumb|Engraving of Mary of Burgundy]] '''Mary''' ({{lang-fr|Marie}}; {{lang-nl|Maria}}; 13 February 1457 – 27 March 1482), [[Duke of Burgundy|Duchess of Burgundy]], reigned over many of the territories of the [[Duchy of Burgundy]], now mainly in [[France]] and the [[Low Countries]], from 1477 until her death. As the only child of [[Charles the Bold]], [[Duke of Burgundy]], and his wife [[Isabella of Bourbon]], she inherited the duchy upon the death of her father in the [[Battle of Nancy]] on 5 January 1477.Vaughan, Richard, ''Charles the Bold: the last Valois Duke of Burgundy'', (Boydell Press, 2004), 127 Owing to the great prosperity of many of the territories that comprised the duchy, Mary was often referred to as '''Mary the Rich''' (though this is not usual in English). ==Early years== Mary of Burgundy was born in [[Brussels]] at the ducal castle of [[Coudenberg]], to [[Charles the Bold]], then known as the Count of Charolais, and his wife [[Isabella of Bourbon]]. Her birth, according to the court chronicler [[Georges Chastellain]], was attended by a clap of thunder ringing from the otherwise clear twilight sky. Her godfather was [[Louis XI of France|Louis, Dauphin of France]], in exile in Burgundy at that time; he named her for his mother [[Marie of Anjou]]. Reactions to the child were mixed: the baby's grandfather, Duke [[Philip the Good]], was unimpressed, and "chose not to attend the [baptism] as it was only for a girl", whereas her grandmother [[Isabella of Portugal, Duchess of Burgundy|Isabella of Portugal]] was delighted at the birth of a granddaughter.Taylor, Aline, ''Isabel of Burgundy'' Her illegitimate aunt [[Anna van Bourgondië|Anne]] was assigned as her governess. ==Heir presumptive== Philip the Good died in 1467 and Mary's father assumed control of the duchy of Burgundy. Since her father had no living sons at the time of his accession, Mary became his [[heir presumptive]]. Her father controlled a vast and wealthy domain made up of the [[Duchy of Burgundy]], the [[Free County of Burgundy]], and the majority of the [[Low Countries]]. As a result, her hand in marriage was eagerly sought by a number of princes. The first proposal was received by her father when she was only five years old, in this case to marry the future King [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]]. Later she was approached by [[Charles de Valois, Duc de Berry|Charles, Duke of Berry]], the younger brother of King Louis XI of France, who was intensely annoyed and attempted to prevent the necessary papal dispensation for [[consanguinity]]. [[File:Maria van Bourgondie dubbel vuurijzer 1478 Vlaanderen.jpg|thumb|left|Flanders, double Briquet, struck under Mary of Burgundy in 1478]] As soon as Louis succeeded in producing a male heir who survived infancy, the future King [[Charles VIII of France]], Louis wanted him to be the one to marry Mary, even though he was thirteen years younger than Mary was. [[Nicholas I, Duke of Lorraine]], was a few years older than Mary and controlled a duchy that lay alongside Burgundian territory, but his plan to combine his domain with hers was ended by his death in battle in 1473. ==Reign== Mary assumed the rule of her father's domains upon his defeat in battle and death on 5 January 1477. King Louis XI of France seized the opportunity to attempt to take possession of the Duchy of Burgundy proper and also the regions of [[Franche-Comté]], [[Picardy]] and [[Artois]]. The king was anxious that Mary should marry his son Charles and thus secure the inheritance of the [[Low Countries]] for his heirs, by force of arms if necessary. Burgundy, fearing French military power, sent an [[Diplomatic mission|embassy]] to France to negotiate a marriage between Mary and the six-year-old Dauphin (later King Charles VIII), but returned home without a betrothal; the French king's demands of cession of territories to the French crown were deemed unacceptable.{{cite book|first=H. G.|last=Koenigsberger|title=Monarchies, States Generals and Parliaments: The Netherlands in the Fifteenth and Sixteenth Centuries|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2001|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2V1dbsvEWnkC|isbn=9780521803304}}{{rp|49}} ===The Great Privilege=== Mary was compelled to sign a charter of rights known as the [[Great Privilege]] in [[Ghent]] on 10 February 1477 on the occasion of her formal recognition as her father's heir (the "[[Joyous Entry]]"). Under this agreement, the provinces and towns of [[Flanders]], [[Duchy of Brabant|Brabant]], [[County of Hainaut|Hainaut]], and [[Count of Holland|Holland]] recovered all the local and communal rights that had been abolished by the decrees of the dukes of Burgundy in their efforts to create a centralized state on the French model out of their disparate holdings in the Low Countries. In particular, the [[Parliament of Mechelen]] (established formally by Charles the Bold in 1470) was abolished and replaced with the pre-existing authority of the [[Parliament of Paris]], which was considered an amenable counterweight to the encroaching centralization undertaken by both Charles the Bold and Philip the Good. The duchess also had to undertake not to declare war, make peace, or raise taxes without the consent of these provinces and towns and only to employ native residents in official posts. Such was the hatred of the people for the old regime that in spite of the duchess's tears and entreaties, two of her father's most influential councilors, the Chancellor Hugonet and the [[Guy of Brimeu|Sire d'Humbercourt]], were executed in Ghent after it was discovered that they were in correspondence with the king of France. ===Marriage=== [[File:Marriage of Mary of Burgundy and Maximilian of Austria.jpg|thumb|Marriage of Mary of Burgundy and Maximilian of Austria]] Mary soon made her choice among the many suitors for her hand by selecting [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Maximilian of Austria]], the future Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I, who became her co-ruler.Paul Murray Kendall, ''Louis XI'', (W.W.Norton Co. Inc, 1971), 319. The marriage took place at Ghent on the evening of 16 August 1477.{{cite book|first=Heinz-Dieter|last=Heimann|title=Die Habsburger: Dynastie und Kaiserreiche|isbn=3-406-44754-6|pages=38–45}} Mary's marriage into the [[House of Habsburg]] initiated two centuries of contention between France and the Habsburgs (later of Kings of Spain as well as Holy Roman Emperors), a struggle that climaxed with the [[War of the Spanish Succession]] in the years 1701–1714. In the Netherlands, affairs now went more smoothly; the French aggression was temporarily checked, and internal peace was in large measure restored. ==Death and legacy== In 1482, a falcon hunt in the woods near [[Wijnendale Castle]] was organised by [[Adolph of Cleves, Lord of Ravenstein]], who lived in the castle. Mary loved riding and was hunting with Maximilian and knights of the Court when her horse tripped, threw her in a ditch, and then landed on top of her, breaking her back. She died several weeks later, on 27 March, from internal injuries, having made a detailed will. She was buried in the [[Church of Our Lady, Bruges|Church of Our Lady in Bruges]] on April 3, 1482.{{cite web| url = http://visitbruges.be/location/must-sees/onze-lieve-vrouwekerk-church-of-our-lady#| title = ONZE-LIEVE-VROUWEKERK (CHURCH OF OUR LADY)| accessdate = March 13, 2014| publisher = VisitBruges.com| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140313140732/http://visitbruges.be/location/must-sees/onze-lieve-vrouwekerk-church-of-our-lady| archivedate = March 13, 2014| df = }} Her 2-year-old daughter, [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]], was sent in vain to France, to marry the Dauphin, in an attempt to please Louis XI and persuade him not to invade the territories owned by Mary. Louis was swift to re-engage hostilities with Maximilian and forced him to agree to the [[Treaty of Arras (1482)|Treaty of Arras of 1482]], by which [[Franche-Comté]] and [[Artois]] passed for a time to French rule, only to be recovered by the [[Treaty of Senlis]] of 1493, which established peace in the Low Countries. Mary's marriage into the House of Habsburg would prove to be a disaster for France, since the Burgundian inheritance would later bring it into conflict with Spain and the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. ==Family== [[Image:Grafmarg.JPG|thumb|right|Mary's tomb effigy in the [[Church of Our Lady, Bruges|Church of Our Lady]], Bruges.]] Mary's son Philip succeeded to her dominions under the guardianship of his father.{{EB1911|wstitle=Mary, duchess of Burgundy|volume=17||page=824|inline=1}} Her children were as follows: * [[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome]] (22 July 1478 – 25 September 1506), who succeeded his mother as Philip IV of Burgundy and became Philip I of Castile through his marriage to [[Joanna of Castile]] (known to history as "Juana la Loca").Charles W. Ingrao, ''The Habsburg Monarchy, 1618–1815'', (Cambridge University Press, 2000), 4. * [[Margaret of Habsburg (1480-1530)|Margaret]] (10 January 1480 – 1 December 1530), married to first to [[Juan, Prince of Asturias]], the son and heir of King [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]] and Queen [[Isabella I of Castile]], and secondly to [[Philibert II, Duke of Savoy]]. * Francis (2 September 1481 – 26 December 1481). ===Ancestry=== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Mary, Duchess of Burgundy ''' |2= 2. [[Charles the Bold|Charles I, Duke of Burgundy]] |3= 3. [[Isabella of Bourbon]] |4= 4. [[Philip the Good|Philip III, Duke of Burgundy]] |5= 5. [[Isabella of Portugal, Duchess of Burgundy|Isabella of Portugal]] |6= 6. [[Charles I, Duke of Bourbon]] |7= 7. [[Agnes of Burgundy, Duchess of Bourbon|Agnes of Burgundy]] |8= 8. [[John the Fearless|John I, Duke of Burgundy]] |9= 9. [[Margaret of Bavaria]] |10= 10. [[John I of Portugal]] |11= 11. [[Philippa of Lancaster]] |12= 12. [[John I, Duke of Bourbon]] |13= 13. [[Marie, Duchess of Auvergne]] |14= 14. [[John the Fearless|John I, Duke of Burgundy]] (= 8) |15= 15. [[Margaret of Bavaria]] (= 9) |16= 16. [[Philip the Bold|Philip II, Duke of Burgundy]] |17= 17. [[Margaret III, Countess of Flanders]] |18= 18. [[Albert I, Duke of Bavaria]] |19= 19. [[Margaret of Brieg]] |20= 20. [[Peter I of Portugal]] |21= 21. [[Teresa Lourenço]] |22= 22. [[John of Gaunt|John of Gaunt, 1st Duke of Lancaster]] |23= 23. [[Blanche of Lancaster]] |24= 24. [[Louis II, Duke of Bourbon]] |25= 25. [[Anne of Auvergne]] |26= 26. [[John, Duke of Berry]] |27= 27. [[Joan of Armagnac]] |28= 28. [[Philip the Bold|Philip II, Duke of Burgundy]] (= 16) |29= 29. [[Margaret III, Countess of Flanders]] (= 17) |30= 30. [[Albert I, Duke of Bavaria]] (= 18) |31= 31. 1581.png|border|36px]] 5 January 1477 – 27 March 1482: [[Count of Zutphen|Countess of Zutphen]] ==See also== {{Portal|Kingdom of France|Biography}} *[[Dukes of Burgundy family tree]] *[[List of horse revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Mikhail Frunze
Михаил Фрунзе | image = Frunze Mikhail 2.jpg | width = 200px | caption = | nationality = [[Soviet people|Soviet]] | office = [[Minister of Defence (Soviet Union)|People's Commissar for Military and Naval Affairs]] | term_start = 15 January 1925 | term_end = 31 October 1925 | 1blankname = Premier | 1namedata = [[Alexey Rykov]] | predecessor = [[Leon Trotsky]] | successor = [[Kliment Voroshilov]] |office1 = Candidate member of the [[13th Politburo of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|13th]] [[Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Politburo]] |term_start1 = 2 June 1924 |term_end1 = 31 October 1925 |birth_name=Mikhail Vasilyevich Frunze | birth_date = {{Birth date|1885|2|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bishkek|Pishpek]], [[Semirechye Oblast]], [[Russian Turkestan]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1925|10|31|1885|2|2|df=y}} | death_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | spouse = | profession = | signature =Mikhail Frunze Signature.svg | party = [[All-Union Communist Party (bolsheviks)]] |2blankname=Party Aliases |2namedata = Mikhailov (Миха́йлов)
Arsenyev (Арсе́ньев)
Trifonych (Три́фоныч) |3blankname=Pen Names |3namedata =Sergei Petrov (Серге́й Петро́в)
A. Shuisky (А. Шу́йский)
M. Mirsky (М. Ми́рский) }} '''Mikhail Vasilyevich Frunze''' (2 February 1885 – 31 October 1925) was a [[Bolshevik]] leader during and just prior to the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]]. He was a major Red Army commander in the [[Russian Civil War]] and is best known for defeating [[Pyotr Wrangel|Baron Wrangel]] in Crimea. ==Life and political activity== [[File:Mikhail Frunze Sophia Frunze 1917.jpg|left|thumb|Mikhail Frunze and his wife Sophia Frunze. Minsk 1917.]] Frunze was born in [[Bishkek|Pishpek]] (present-day Bishkek in [[Kyrgyzstan]]), then a small [[Russian Empire|Imperial Russian]] garrison town in the [[Kyrgyzstan|Kyrgyz]] part of [[Russian Turkestan]] ([[Semirechye Oblast]]), to a [[Romanian people|Romanian]]{{cite news|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CMloAAAAMAAJ&q=%22part+Romanian%22&dq=%22part+Romanian%22&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y|page=194|title=Lenin: A Political Life: Volume 3: The Iron Ring|year=1995|author=[[Robert Service (historian)|Robert Service]] |publisher=''Indiana University Press''|isbn=978-0253351814|accessdate=24 June 2013}} para-medic ([[feldsher]]) (originally from the [[Kherson Governorate]]) and his [[Russians|Russian]]Martin McCauley, ''Who's Who in Russia Since 1900'', [[Routledge]], 1997, {{ISBN|0-415-13897-3}}, p. 87-88 wife. He began his studies at [[Almaty|Verniy]] (present-day Almaty), and in 1904 he attended the [[Saint Petersburg Polytechnical University]].Martin McCauley, ''Who's Who in Russia Since 1900'', [[Routledge]], 1997, {{ISBN|0-415-13897-3}}, p. 87-88{{ru icon}}M.V. Frunze, ''Autobiography'', 1921 from М.В. Фрунзе: Военная и политическая деятельность, М.: Воениздат, 1984, hosted at [http://il2.is74.ru/airwar/militera-mirror/bio/frunze/pre1.html Militera project]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} At the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party|Second Congress]] of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party|Social Democratic Party Labour Party]] in [[London]] (1903), during the ideological split between [[Vladimir Lenin]] and [[Julius Martov]], the two main party [[leader]]s, over party tactics (Martov argued for a large party of activists, whilst Lenin wanted a small group of [[professional revolutionaries]] with a large fringe group of sympathisers), Frunze sided with Lenin's majority, the so-called ''Bolsheviks'' ("majoritarians"), opposed to Martov's minority, the ''[[Mensheviks]]'' (or "minoritarians"). Two years after the Second Congress Frunze became an important leader in the [[Russian Revolution of 1905|1905 Revolution]], at the head of striking [[textile]] workers in [[Shuya, Ivanovo Oblast|Shuya]] and [[Ivanovo]]. Following the disastrous end of the movement, Frunze was arrested in 1907 and [[Capital punishment|sentenced to death]], spending several months on [[death row]] awaiting his execution.Триумф и Трагедия - И. В. Сталин: политический портрет. (Triumph and Tragedy - I. V. Stalin : A Political Portrait) Дмитрий Волкогонов ([[Dmitri Volkogonov]]). Book 1, Part 1, PP. 127. Новости Publications. Moscow. 1989. but he was later reprieved and his sentence was commuted to life at [[Penal labour|hard labour]]. After 10 years in [[Siberia]]n prisons, Frunze escaped to [[Chita, Zabaykalsky Krai|Chita]], where he became editor of the Bolshevik weekly newspaper ''Vostochnoe Obozrenie'' (Eastern Perspective). During the [[February Revolution]], Frunze headed the [[Minsk]] civilian [[militia]] before his election as president of the [[Belarus|Byelorussian]] [[Soviet (council)|Soviet]]. He later went to [[Moscow]] and led an armed force of workers to aid in the struggle for control of the city. ==Russian Civil War== [[File:Béla Kun, Jacques Sadoul, Leon Trotsky, Mikhail Frunze, Sergey Gusev 1920.jpg|thumb|[[Béla Kun]], [[Jacques Sadoul (politician)|Jacques Sadoul]], [[Leon Trotsky]], Mikhail Frunze and [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]]. Kharkiv Ukraine 1920.]] After the [[October Revolution]] of 1917, Frunze became [[Political commissar|Military Commissar]] for the [[Ivanovo|Ivanovo-Voznesensk]] Province in 1918. In the course of the [[Russian Civil War]] of 1917-1922, he was appointed as head of the Southern Army Group of the {{Interlanguage link multi| Red Army Eastern Front | ru |3= Восточный фронт РККА}} (March 1919). After Frunze's troops defeated Admiral [[Alexander Kolchak]] and the [[White movement|White Army]] in [[Omsk]], [[Leon Trotsky]] (the head of the [[Red Army]]) gave overall command of the Eastern Front to him (19 July 1919). Frunze went on to rid his native [[Turkestan]] of [[Basmachi Revolt|Basmachi insurgents]] and of [[White Army | White]] troops. He captured [[Khiva]] in February and [[Bukhara]] in September 1920. In November 1920, Frunze's army retook the [[Crimea]] and managed to push White general [[Pyotr Wrangel]] and his troops out of Russia. He also led, as commander of the southern front, the destruction of [[Nestor Makhno]]'s [[Anarchism|anarchist]] movement in [[Ukraine]] and the [[nationalist]] movement of [[Symon Petliura]]. In December 1921, Frunze visited Ankara during [[Turkish War of Independence]] as an ambassador of the [[Ukrainian SSR]] and established Turkish - Soviet relations. [[Mustafa Kemal Ataturk]] valued him as an ally and a friend, to the extent that he placed a statue of Frunze as a part of the [[Republic Monument]] at the [[Taksim Square]], in Istanbul. [[File:Leon Trotsky attends The October Revolution parade 1924.jpg|left|thumb|From left [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Leon Trotsky]], [[Mikhail Kalinin]] and Mikhail Frunze attend [[October Revolution|The October Revolution]] parade on [[Red Square]] 7 November 1924.]] In 1921, he was elected to the [[Central Committee]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Russian Bolshevik Party]], on 2 June 1924 became candidate member of the [[13th Politburo of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Politburo]] and in January, 1925, became the Chairman of the [[Revolutionary Military Council]]. Frunze's support of [[Grigory Zinoviev]] brought him into conflict with [[Joseph Stalin]], one of Zinoviev's chief opponents, with whom they had previously been on amiable terms, owing to the respect that Stalin studiously displayed at that period towards his fellow "old guard" revolutionary and former prisoner.Триумф и Трагедия - И. В. Сталин: политический портрет. (Triumph and Tragedy - I. V. Stalin : A Political Portrait) Дмитрий Волкогонов [[Dmitri Volkogonov]]. Book 1, Part 1, PP. 127. Новости Publications. Moscow. 1989. ==Death== Frunze had been noted among communist leaders as possessing a very creative and almost unorthodox view on matters of implementation and policy. He gained the respect and admiration of his comrades thanks to his fearless and successful pursuit of complicated military objectives and his endurance during the illegality period of the communist party. He had been considered as a potential successor to Lenin, due to his strength in both theoretical and practical matters of advancing the Communist party agenda, and his seeming lack of personal ambition separate from the party.Триумф и Трагедия - И. В. Сталин: политический портрет. (Triumph and Tragedy - I. V. Stalin : A Political Portrait) Дмитрий Волкогонов [[Dmitri Volkogonov]]. Book 1, Part 1, PP. 127. Новости Publications. Moscow. 1989. Frunze was suffering from a chronic [[gastric ulcer|ulceration]], and although it had been suggested to him many times that he undergo surgery, he tended to favour more conservative treatments. After an especially severe episode in 1925, Frunze was hospitalised. Stalin and [[Anastas Mikoyan]] both came to visit him, and impressed on him the need for an operation. [[File:Mikhail Frunze funeral Nov 3 1925.jpg|thumb|Mikhail Frunze funeral 3 November 1925]] Not long before his death, Frunze wrote to his wife: "At present I am feeling absolutely healthy, and it seems ridiculous to even think of, and even more-so to undergo an operation. Nevertheless, both party representatives are requiring it."Триумф и Трагедия - И. В. Сталин: политический портрет. (Triumph and Tragedy - I. V. Stalin : A Political Portrait) Дмитрий Волкогонов [[Dmitri Volkogonov]]. Book 1, Part 1, PP. 128. Новости Publications. Moscow. 1989. Frunze died on 31 October 1925. There has been speculation that Stalin or another rival within the party secretly ordered his death, but there is no evidence to support this.V. Topolyansky. ''Blow from the past.'' (Russian: В. Торолянский. ''Сквозняк из прошлого.'') Novaya Gazeta/InaPress. Moscow. 2006. {{ISBN|5-87135-183-2}}. However, Frunze was administered a [[chloroform]] dose that seven times exceeded the dose normally applied to induce [[Unconsciousness|narcosis]].[http://iz.ru/news/367427 Who Killed Mikhail Frunze] / Кто убил Михаила Фрунзе. Izvestiya. 26 October 2010 Frunze was buried in the [[Kremlin Wall Necropolis]]. ==Legacy== [[File:Mikhail Frunze by Isaak Brodsky (1929).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Frunze by [[Isaak Brodsky]].]] In 1926, the capital city of [[Bishkek]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], was renamed ''Frunze'' in his honour. It reverted to its former name in 1991. Nevertheless, Frunze himself is still commemorated in the city. His equestrian statue still stands in front of the main railway station. A street and a museum in the centre of the city are named after him; the museum contains the cottage in which he grew up, fully intact inside a larger modern structure. Multiple villages bear the name [[Frunze, Russia]]. The [[Frunze Military Academy]], one of the most respected in the former [[Soviet Union]], was also named in his honour. The [[Soviet 2nd Rifle Division]] was in the past known as 2nd Belarusian Red Banner Rifle Division in the name of M.V. Frunze. There are stations named ''Frunzenskaya'' in his honour on the [[Frunzenskaya (Moscow Metro)|Moscow Metro]], [[Frunzenskaya (Saint Petersburg Metro)|Saint Petersburg Metro]] and [[Frunzenskaya (Minsk Metro)|Minsk Metro]], and a stone carving of his likeness stands at one end of the station. [[Shuya, Ivanovo Oblast|Shuya]] is home to a memorial museum dedicated to Frunze. Streets in many Russian cities are named after him. After his death, the first name for boys Frunzik (roughly "Little Frunze") became quite popular in the Caucusus and Soviet Turkestan, the most famous name-bearer probably being [[Frunzik Mkrtchyan]].http://kino.ukr.net/persons/543/ The [[Russian battleship Poltava (1911)|Russian battleship Poltava]] was renamed ''Frunze'' in his honour in January 1926, as was the second Kirov-class nuclear battlecruiser (now the "[[Admiral Lazarev]]") in 1981. General Frunze is also honoured with a place right behind Ataturk, in the Monument of the Republic, located at the heart of Taksim Square, in Istanbul, Turkey. ==Literary depictions== [[Boris Pilnyak]]'s story ''The Tale of the Unextinguished Moon'' was based on Frunze's death. His death also forms the central element of the first two chapters of [[Vasily Aksyonov]]'s novel ''[[Generations of Winter]]''. ==Quotes== *"All that we do, every action, should correspond to the highest ideals of the Revolution." *"The [[Red Army]] was created by the workers and peasants and is led by the will of the [[working class]]. That will is being carried out by the united Communist Party." ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{Cite book |last=Gareev |first=M.A. |title=M.V. Frunze, Military Theorist |publisher=Pergamon-Brassey's |location=Washington, D.C. |year=1987 |isbn=0-08-035183-2 }} * {{Cite book |last=Jacobs |first=Walter Darnell |title=Frunze: The Soviet Clausewitz, 1885–1925 |year=1969 |publisher=Martinus Nijhoff |location=The Hague}} == External links == {{Commons category|Mikhail Frunze}} *[http://russiapedia.rt.com/prominent-russians/politics-and-society/mikhail-frunze/ Prominent Russians: Mikhail Frunze] ''Russiapedia'' *[http://www-personal.ksu.edu/~stone/sources Frunze's writings on military theory] * {{PM20|FID=pe/005666}} {{S-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box |before = [[Pavel Pavlovich Lebedev|Pavel Lebedev]] |title = [[Chief of the General Staff (Russia)|Chief of the page.title: Murder of Jay Cook and Tanya Van Cuylenborg

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jay Cook | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[British Columbia]] | death_date = 18 November 1987 (aged 20) | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | body_discovered = 26 November 1987 | mother = | father = }} {{Infobox person | name = Tanya Van Cuylenborg | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[British Columbia]] | death_date = 18 November 1987 (aged 18) | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | body_discovered = 24 November 1987 | mother = | father = }} '''Jay Cook''' (1967–1987) and '''Tanya Van Cuylenborg''' (1969–1987) were a [[Canadians|Canadian]] couple from [[Saanich, British Columbia]], who were murdered while on a trip to [[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]] in November 1987. On 18 May 2018 the [[Snohomish County]] Sheriff's Office announced they had arrested a suspect in the case.
== Events prior to the murders == Cook and Van Cuylenborg met in high school and had been in a relationship for about six months.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://unsolved.com/gallery/jay-cook-and-tanya-van-cuylenborg/|title=Jay Cook and Tanya Van Cuylenborg - Unsolved Mysteries|work=[[Unsolved Mysteries]]|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-US}}</ref> On 18 November 1987, they left in Cook's father's bronze 1977 [[Ford E series#Third generation (1975–1991)|Ford Club]] van for an overnight trip to the Seattle area to purchase parts for Cook's father's business.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/reward-offered-in-push-to-solve-killing-of-victoria-couple-in-1987-1.1985532|title=Reward offered in push to solve killing of Victoria couple in 1987|last=Smart|first=Amy|work=[[Times Colonist]]|date=2015-06-30|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref>
Cook and Van Cuylenborg took the [[MV Coho]] ferry from Victoria to [[Port Angeles, Washington|Port Angeles]], Washington. They then drove south-east on [[U.S. Route 101 in Washington|Route 101]] to [[Bremerton, Washington|Bremerton]], where they boarded a second ferry to Seattle. A fuel receipt later found in the van confirms that they purchased fuel on the road between Port Angeles and Bremerton.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/2079753/crime-stoppers-what-happened-to-jay-cook-and-tanya-van-cuylenborg/|title=Crime Stoppers: What happened to Jay Cook and Tanya Van Cuylenborg?|first=Jon|last=Azpiri|work=[[Global News]]|date=2015-06-27|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-ca}}</ref> The pair were last seen boarding the ferry in Bremerton.
Cook's and Van Cuylenborg's families became concerned when the couple did not return home as planned on 19 November and did not make contact. On 20 November, they were reported missing.
== The murders == On 24 November, Tanya Van Cuylenborg's half-naked body was found in a ditch by a rural road near [[Alger, Washington|Alger]], in [[Skagit County, Washington|Skagit County]], Washington, a short distance south of [[Bellingham, Washington|Bellingham]].<ref name=":2" /> She had been raped, bound with plastic ties and shot in the head.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/International+team+tries+crack+unsolved+1987+murders+Victoria+couple/2417538/story.html|title=International team tries to crack unsolved 1987 murders of Victoria couple|last=Boswell|first=Randy|work=[[Vancouver Sun]]|date=2010-01-07|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-ca}}</ref> Investigators initially considered Cook a suspect, though both Cook's and Van Cuylenborg's families vehemently rejected this possibility.
On 25 November, Tanya's wallet and keys were found discarded near the [[Greyhound Lines|Greyhound]] station in Bellingham. The van was found a few blocks away. Inside the van were plastic ties of the same type used to bind Tanya, plastic gloves, and various receipts, including the Bremerton-Seattle ferry ticket, confirming the belief that the couple had taken the second ferry. However, Tanya's [[Minolta X-700]] 35 mm camera, which she had brought on the trip, was missing and has never been recovered.<ref name="king" />
On 26 November, Jay Cook's body was discovered nearly 60 miles<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mynorthwest.com/951649/jay-cook-tanya-van-cuylenborg-cold-case/|title=Snohomish, Skagit cold case gets momentum with modern DNA science|work=[[KIRO-TV]]|date=2018-04-11|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en-ca}}</ref> from where Tanya's body was found two days earlier. Jay had been beaten with rocks and strangled.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="global">{{citenews|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4278799/tanya-van-cuylenborg-jay-cook-murder/|title=Second murder charge filed against Washington State trucker in 1987 deaths of Saanich couple|work=[[Global News]]|date=2018-06-16|accessdate=2018-10-17|first=Jon|last=Azpiri}}</ref>
== Investigation and later events == The police believed that the killer was taunting them by leaving the plastic gloves in plain view. Detective Robert Gebo of the Seattle Police Department stated: "He leaves those behind as a sign to the police that you needn't look for fingerprints because I wore these gloves. And he has confidence that there's nothing that's going to connect him with these crimes."<ref name=":0" />
The police were in fact able to obtain the suspect's [[DNA profiling|DNA]] from the van, although there has been no match on any of the criminal databases.<ref name=":3" /> Despite the lack of a match, the police believe that the specific manner in which the victims were killed (which has not been revealed in detail publicly) suggests that the killer is familiar with the prison system.<ref name=":0" /> The lack of a match despite a potential prison background may be explained by the suspect being incarcerated before the DNA collection of criminals became commonplace or technologically possible.
Investigators believe that the couple may have met their killer on one of the ferries, most likely the second one, and offered him a ride when reaching Seattle.<ref name=":0" />
In the months after the murders, both victims' families received a series of taunting greetings cards featuring graphic descriptions of the murders.<ref name=":0" /> The cards bore postmarks from Seattle, [[Los Angeles]] and [[New York City|New York]], and were written by the same person. In 2010, it was announced that the writer of the cards had been found: a 78-year-old Canadian transient with mental health issues. The police have confirmed that he is not the killer and has no connection to the crime.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.heraldnet.com/news/author-of-taunting-letters-found-but-cleared-of-1987-killings/|first=Diana|last=Hefley|title=Author of taunting letters found but cleared of 1987 killings|work=[[The Herald (Everett)|HeraldNet]]|date=2010-08-27|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en-ca}}</ref>
On 11 April 2018, a composite sketch of the suspect was released based on the DNA collected at the crime scene using a process called "snapshot DNA phenotyping"<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://komonews.com/news/local/cops-release-suspect-sketch-in-1987-murder-of-young-couple|title=Cops release suspect sketch in unsolved 1987 murder of young couple|work=[[KOMO (AM)|KOMO]]|date=2018-04-11|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en-ca}}</ref><ref name="king">{{citenews|url=https://www.king5.com/article/news/crime/detectives-release-new-sketches-ask-for-help-in-1987-double-murder/281-537349452|first1=Taylor|last1=McAvoy|first2=Eric|last2=Wilkinson|title=Detectives release new sketches, ask for help in 1987 double-murder|work=[[KING-TV]]|date=2018-04-11|accessdate=2018-10-17}}</ref> and the case was also investigated using genetic genealogy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencenews.org/article/genetic-sleuthing-murder-suspect-cold-case-talbott|title=Genetic sleuthing again IDs a murder suspect in a cold case|last=Saey|first=Tina Hesman|date=2018-05-23|work=[[Science News]]|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en}}</ref>
On 18 May 2018, Snohomish County Sheriff announced that William Earl Talbot, II, 55, was arrested for the murder of Van Cuylenborg.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/seattle-man-arrested-in-connection-with-1987-slayings-of-b-c-high-school-sweethearts-1.4669139|title=DNA genealogy match leads to arrest in 1987 slayings of B.C. high school sweethearts|work=[[CBC News]]|first=Karin|last=Larsen|date=2018-05-18|accessdate=2018-08-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Detectives from the Snohomish and Skagit County Sheriff's Offices arrested a 55YO SeaTac Man for the 11/1987 murder of Jay Cook and Tanya Van Cuylenborg|url=https://twitter.com/SnoCoSheriff/status/997538421093548032|website=[[Twitter]]|date=2018-05-18|accessdate=2018-05-18}}</ref> On June 16, 2018, a second aggravated first-degree murder charge was laid, for the murder of Jay Cook.<ref name="global" /> Talbott pleaded not guilty to both these charges.<ref>{{cite news |last=Wanielista |first=Kera |url=https://www.goskagit.com/news/cold-case-murder-suspect-pleads-not-guilty/article_c1f69ff4-53ae-5148-90aa-2a943182cab5.html |title=Cold case murder suspect pleads not guilty |work=GoSkagit |date=2018-06-19 |accessdate=2018-06-27}}</ref>
The case, and specifically finding the killer via public genealogical websites, was featured on a Season 4 episode of the Criminology podcast.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.stitcher.com/podcast/criminology/e/56708108|title=S4 Ep3 - The Murders of Jay Cook and Tanya Van Cuylenborg|date=2018-10-13|accessdate=2018-10-17|publisher=Criminology}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of people who disappeared]] *[[List of unsolved deaths]]

{{ref improve|date=February 2014}} The '''muzzle clamp''' is a method of killing used by large [[Predation|predators]], usually [[cat]]s such as ''Panthera leo'', the [[lion]], ''Panthera pardus'', the [[leopard]], and ''Panthera uncia'', the [[snow leopard]]. It requires the subduing of [[prey]], usually completely on the ground and pinned by the predator, and the engulfing of the [[Snout|muzzle]] of the prey in the mouth of the predator, blocking [[Respiration (physiology)|respiration]] through either the mouth or nose.<ref>{{cite book|last=Turner|first=Alan|title=Big Cats and their Fossil Relatives|year=1997|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=0-231-10229-1}}</ref>
==Usage== It is generally easier for large, social carnivores to use this method with large prey when there are multiple individuals holding the prey still while it suffocates, in the case of the lion, or for solitary carnivores killing weak or small animals. It is not as common as the [[throat clamp]] with cats. It is also a calculated measure not seen often because most predators are known, especially [[canids]] and [[hyaenids]], for eating the prey while it's still alive and letting it die of loss of blood and/or shock, not bothering with killing it first. This method also silences the prey for the most part and can be used by [[Solitary animal|solitary]] animals to keep the noise down as not to attract other predators with the commotion.
==Anatomy== [[Canine teeth|Canines]] that are strong and not too long are generally essential for this method because any rapid movement of the head of the prey can break long or fragile canines and canines that are too short won't penetrate into the muscle and skin of the muzzle far enough and the prey can pull free. The predator cannot breath through its mouth when applying a muzzle clamp and must resort to breathing through the nose, which causes the issue of not enough oxygen if the predator is exhausted since panting through the mouth is much more efficient than breathing through the nose for most predators. If the predator is too tired, it may resort to another method of killing or withhold from finishing the prey off until it catches its breath.

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Orgasmic Birth: The Best-Kept Secret | director = Debra Pascali-Bonaro | producer = Debra Pascali-Bonaro
Kris Liem | music = John McDowell
Sabina Sciubba | editing = Kris Liem | released = '''United States:''' January 2, 2009 (first primetime showing) | runtime = 85 minutes | language = [[English language|English]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] }} '''''Orgasmic Birth: The Best-Kept Secret''''' (also called '''''Orgasmic Birth: 11 Mothers, 12 International Experts''''' or just '''''Orgasmic Birth''''') is a 2008 [[documentary film]] that examines the intimate nature of birth.[http://www.orgasmicbirth.com/what-is-orgasmic-birth Orgasmicbirth.com, What is Orgasmic Birth] It had been shown at women's and film festivals since May 2008, before being shown for the first time in [[primetime]] on January 2, 2009 by ABC’s [[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]].{{cite web|last=Belkin |first=Lisa |url=http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/11/orgasms-during-childbirth/ |title=Orgasms During Childbirth? - NYTimes.com |publisher=Parenting.blogs.nytimes.com |date=2008-12-11 |accessdate=2012-07-19}} The documentary follows the journey of eleven women through labour, presenting how blissful birth can be.{{cite news | url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1668525751.html | title= Orgasmic Birth: The Best Kept Secret | publisher=''Contemporary Sexuality'' | author= Linda Newhart Lotz | date= March 1, 2009 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}}{{cite news | url= http://www.theage.com.au/opinion/orgasmic-birth-and-other-old-midwives-tales-20081229-76sd.html | title= Orgasmic birth and other old midwives' tales | publisher=''[[The Age]]'' | author= Avril Moore | date=December 30, 2008 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}}{{cite news | url= http://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=6120045&page=1 | title= Labor Orgasms Called 'Best-Kept Secret' | publisher=''[[ABC News]]'' | author= [[Juju Chang]] and Gail Deutsch | date=December 9, 2008 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}} Interviews with experts, ([[doula]]s, doctors, [[Midwifery|midwives]], [[Gynaecology|gynecologists]], [[anthropology|anthropologists]], [[Neonatology|neonatologists]], nurses, [[Lamaze technique|Lamaze]] educators, and mothers and fathers) explore how the birthing process has become a medical procedure rather than a natural process.{{cite news | url= http://www.greenmuze.com/reviews/films/856-orgasmic-birth-.html | title= Orgasmic Birth | publisher=''Greenmuze.com'' | author= | date=February 24, 2009 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}} Noted narrators include [[Ina May Gaskin]]. While the documentary features several mothers who claim to have had an [[birthgasm|orgasm during labor]], it is primarily about natural labour at the home without drugs.{{cite news | url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/health/2009/0324/1224243299509.html | title= The orgasmic way to avoid hard labour | publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]'' | author= Viv Groskop | date= March 24, 2009 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}}{{cite news | url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23239361/ | title= Pioneering midwife touts 'orgasmic birth' | publisher=''[[MSNBC]] (AP)'' | author= | date= February 24, 2008 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}} ==Book== ''Orgasmic Birth: Your Guide to a Safe, Satisfying, and Pleasurable Birth Experience'' by Elizabeth Davis and Debra Pascali-Bonaro, was first published on June 8, 2010. ==DVD release== The [[DVD]] was released in the United States on January 1, 2009, and soon after an international version was released.[http://orgasmicbirth.com OrgasmicBirth.com] ==Soundtrack== The [[soundtrack]] was created by John McDowell (composer of the score for the documentary ''[[Born Into Brothels]]''), with additional composition by Sabina Sciubba (of the group [[Brazilian Girls]]). It is available to buy on [[CD]]. ==See also== *''[[The Business of Being Born]]'' *[[Homebirth]] *[[Waterbirth]] ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.orgasmicbirth.com/ Official Website] *{{IMDb title|1331111|Orgasmic Birth: The Best-Kept Secret}} [[Category:Books and art about childbirth]] [[Category:Orgasm]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Pregnancy films]]

{{Infobox animal | name = Pelorus Jack | image = Pelorus Jack.jpg | caption = Pelorus Jack in 1909 | alt = | birth_name = | othername = | species = Risso's dolphin | breed = | gender = | birth_date = <!--5 October 1878 (added by an anon... where does this date come from?)--> | birth_place = | death_date = <!--22 April 1912 (added by an anon... where does this date come from?)--> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | relativeage = | nationality = | employer = | role = | years_active = 1888–1912 | known = Escorting ships near [[French Pass]] | awards = | occupation = Dolphin | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = | parents = | children = | weight = | height = | appearance = White colour with grey lines or shadings; round, white head | namedafter = [[Pelorus Sound]], in the [[Marlborough Sounds]], [[New Zealand]] | website = }} {{Location map |New Zealand |label=Cook Strait |lat_dir=S | lat_deg=41 | lat_min=13 | lat_sec=46 |lon_dir=E | lon_deg=174 | lon_min=28 | lon_sec=59 |position=bottom |width= 160 |float=right |caption=Location of Cook Strait }} '''Pelorus Jack''' ([[floruit|fl.]] 1888 – April 1912) was a [[Risso's dolphin]] that was famous for meeting and escorting ships through a stretch of water in [[Cook Strait]], [[New Zealand]], between 1888 and 1912. Pelorus Jack was usually spotted in [[Admiralty Bay, New Zealand|Admiralty Bay]] between Cape Francis and Collinet Point, near [[French Pass]], a notoriously dangerous channel used by ships travelling between [[Wellington]] and [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]].
Pelorus Jack was shot at from a passing ship, and was later protected by a 1904 New Zealand law.
== Appearance ==
Pelorus Jack was approximately {{convert|13|ft|0}} long and was of a white color with grey lines or shadings, and a round, white head.<ref name="pelorus-jack-com">{{cite web|url = http://www.pelorus-jack.com/about/legend.html | title = The Legend of Pelorus Jack | publisher = pelorus-jack.com | accessdate = 17 August 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080121191804/http://www.pelorus-jack.com/about/legend.html | archivedate = 21 January 2008 | deadurl = yes}}</ref> Although its sex was never determined, it was identified from photographs as a [[Risso's dolphin]], ''Grampus griseus''. This is an uncommon species in New Zealand waters, and only 12 Risso's dolphins have been reported in that area.<ref name="uwnz">{{cite web|author = Parkinson, Brian | url = http://www.ecotours.co.nz/Brian/wildlife/nelson/pelorus.htm | publisher = Ecotours New Zealand | title = Unique Wildlife of New Zealand - Pelorus | accessdate = 29 December 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061009020433/http://www.ecotours.co.nz/Brian/wildlife/nelson/pelorus.htm|archivedate=9 October 2006}}</ref>
[[File:The animals of New Zealand; an account of the dominion's air-breathing vertebrates (1909) (14775451543).jpg|thumb|Pelorus Jack. Photographed by A. Pitt.]] == History ==
Pelorus Jack guided the ships by swimming alongside a water craft for 20 minutes at a time. If the crew could not see Jack at first, they often waited for him to appear.
Despite his name, he did not live in nearby [[Pelorus Sound]]; instead, he would often guide ships through dangerous passages of French Pass. However, some local residents familiar with his habits claim that he never went through French Pass itself.<ref name="teara"/>
Pelorus Jack was first seen around 1888 when it appeared in front of the [[schooner]] ''Brindle'' when the ship approached French Pass, a channel located between [[D'Urville Island, New Zealand|D'Urville Island]] and the [[South Island]]. When the members of the crew saw the dolphin bobbing up and down in front of the ship, they wanted to kill him, but the captain’s wife talked them out of it. To their amazement, the dolphin then proceeded to guide the ship through the narrow channel. And for years thereafter, he safely guided almost every ship that came by. With rocks and strong currents, the area is dangerous to ships, but no shipwrecks occurred when Jack was present.<ref>[[John Robbins (author)|Robbins, John]] (2011) [https://books.google.com/books?id=h-9ARz2YAlgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%27%27Diet+for+a+New+America%27+%22John+Robbins%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IyXrUZzUF8euiQeRnYHQAw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA ''Diet for a New America''] H J Kramer, {{ISBN|9781932073416}}. </ref>
Many sailors and travellers saw Pelorus Jack, and he was mentioned in local newspapers and depicted in postcards.
Jack was last seen in April 1912. There were various rumours connected to his disappearance, including fears that foreign whalers might have harpooned him. However, research suggests that Pelorus Jack was an old animal; his head was white and his body pale, both indications of age, so it is likely that he died of natural causes.<ref name="uwnz"/>
Since 1989, Pelorus Jack has been used as a symbol for the [[Interislander]], a ferry service across the Cook Strait, and is incorporated into the livery of the ships in the fleet.<ref>[http://www.nzmaritime.co.nz/railferries.htm New Zealand's Cook Strait Rail Ferries], New Zealand Maritime Record</ref>
=== Shooting incident ===
In 1904, someone aboard the ''[[SS Penguin]]'' tried to shoot Pelorus Jack with a rifle. Despite the attempt on his life, Pelorus Jack continued to help ships. According to folklore, however, he no longer helped the ''Penguin'', which shipwrecked in Cook Strait in 1909.<ref>[http://www.museumofwellington.co.nz/fact_sheets/pelorus_jack.pdf Pelorus Jack fact sheet] at the Museum of Wellington</ref><ref>[http://www.southwest.com.au/~kirbyhs/dolphins3.html The Quest for Wild Dolphins]</ref>
=== Protection ===
Following the shooting incident, a law was proposed to protect Pelorus Jack. He became protected by [[Order in Council]] under the Sea Fisheries Act on 26 September 1904. Pelorus Jack remained protected by that law until his disappearance in 1912. It is believed that he was the first individual sea creature protected by law in any country.<ref name="teara">{{cite web | url = http://www.teara.govt.nz/1966/P/PelorusJack/PelorusJack/en | accessdate = 29 December 2006 | author = Alpers, A.F.G. | title = PELORUS JACK | publisher = An Encyclopaedia of New Zealand 1966 }}</ref>
==Cultural references== "Pelorus Jack" is also a popular Scottish Country dance,<ref>{{cite web |title=Pelorus Jack |url=https://www.scottish-country-dancing-dictionary.com/dance-crib/pelorus-jack.html |website=Scottish Country Dancing Dictionary |accessdate=14 June 2018}} (dance instructions)</ref> named in honour of the dolphin. This dance features a set of alternating tandem half-reels (or hays) where two people act as one but swap who leads at the reel ends, this is now known as a ''Dolphin Reel''.
[[Arthur Ransome]] mentions Pelorus Jack as accompanying ships and receiving protection in his 1932 novel [[Peter Duck]]. However, the character of Peter Duck incorrectly locates the dolphin as living in [[Sydney Harbour]]<ref>{{cite book |last1=Ransome |first1=Arthur |title=Peter Duck : a treasure hunt in the Caribbees |publisher=Godine |isbn=0-87923-660-4 |page=200 |edition=2006}}</ref>.
==See also== *[[Opo (dolphin)]] *[[Moko (dolphin)]] *[[Fungie]]
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
==Further references== * Ross E Hutchins and Jerome P Connolly - ''The saga of Pelorus Jack'' (1971) * Edmund Lindop and Jane Carlson - ''Pelorus Jack'' (1964)
==External links== * [http://www.southwest.com.au/~kirbyhs/dolphins3.html Famous wild dolphins] * [http://www.rscds-canberra.org/texts/Pelorus-30-7-06.pdf The Quest for Pelorus] (PDF) {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}

{{Cleanup|date=May 2009}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | Name = Polyhydramnios | synonyms = Polyhydramnion, hydramnios, polyhydramnios | Image = Ultrasound Scan ND 145330 1455290 cr.png | Caption = | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Polyhydramnios''' is a medical condition describing an excess of [[amniotic fluid]] in the [[amniotic sac]]. It is seen in about 1% of pregnancies.<ref>Alexander, ES, Spitz, HB, Clark, RA. Sonography of polyhydramnios. AJR Am J Roentgenol 1982; 138:343</ref><ref>Hill LM; Breckle R; Thomas ML; Fries JK, Polyhydramnios: ultrasonically detected prevalence and neonatal outcome, Obstet Gynecol 1987 Jan;69(1):21-5, {{PMID|3540761}} </ref><ref>Hobbins JC; Grannum PA; Berkowitz RL; Silverman R; Mahoney MJ,Ultrasound in the diagnosis of congenital anomalies.,Obstet Gynecol 1979 Jun 1;134(3):331-45., {{PMID|453266}}</ref> It is typically diagnosed when the [[amniotic fluid index]] (AFI) is greater than 24 cm.<ref name="Barnhard">Y Barnhard; I Bar-Hava; MY Divon, Is polyhydramnios in an ultrasonographically normal fetus an indication for genetic evaluation?, Obstet Gynecol. 1995 Nov;173(5):1523-7.</ref><ref>Brady K, Polzin WJ, Kopelman JN, Read JA. Risk of chromosomal abnormalities in patients with idiopathic polyhydramnios. Obstet Gynecol 1992;79:234-8.</ref> There are two clinical varieties of polyhydramnios: chronic polyhydramnios where excess amniotic fluid accumulates gradually, and acute polyhydramnios where excess amniotic fluid collects rapidly.
The opposite to polyhydramnios is [[oligohydramnios]], not enough amniotic fluid.
==Causes== [[File:Ultrasound Scan ND 152505 1531230 cr.png|thumb]] In most cases, the exact cause cannot be identified. A single case may have one or more causes, including intrauterine infection ([[TORCH complex|TORCH]]), [[Rh disease|rh-isoimmunisation]], or [[chorioangioma]] of the placenta. In a multiple gestation pregnancy, the cause of polyhydramnios usually is [[twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome]]. Maternal causes include [[cardiac]] problems, [[kidney]] problems, and maternal [[diabetes mellitus]], which causes fetal [[hyperglycemia]] and resulting [[polyuria]] (fetal urine is a major source of amniotic fluid).
A recent study distinguishes between mild and severe polyhydramnios and showed that [[Apgar score]] of less than 7, perinatal death and structural malformations only occurred in women with severe polyhydramnios.<ref>Bundgaard A, Andersen BR, Rode L, Lebech M, Tabor A, Prevalence of polyhydramnios at a Danish hospital--a population-based study. Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand. 2007 ; 86(12): 1427-31.</ref> In another study, all patients with polyhydramnios, that had a sonographically normal fetus, showed no chromosomal anomalies.<ref name="Barnhard" />
(M/C for polyhydramnio is fetal anomalies 'Williams Obstetrics, 24th Edition - Cunningham, Leveno, Bloom et al. Table 11-2) but these anomalies include:
*[[gastrointestinal]] abnormalities such as [[esophageal atresia]] [[duodenal atresia|& duodenal atresia]] (causing inability to swallow amniotic fluid), anencephaly, facial cleft, neck masses, tracheoesophageal fistula, and diaphragmatic hernias. An annular pancreas causing obstruction may also be the cause. *Bochdalek's hernia, in which the pleuro-peritoneal membranes (especially the left) will fail to develop & seal the pericardio- peritoneal canals. This results in the stomach protrusion up into the thoracic cavity, and the fetus is unable to swallow sufficient amounts of amniotic fluid. * fetal [[renal]] disorders that result in increased urine production during pregnancy, such as in antenatal [[Bartter syndrome]].<ref name="pmid18695706">{{cite journal |author=Seyberth HW. |title=An improved terminology and classification of Bartter-like syndromes. |journal=Nat Clin Pract Nephrol |volume=4 |issue=10 |pages=560–7 |year=2008 |pmid=18695706 |doi=10.1038/ncpneph0912}}</ref> Molecular diagnosis is available for these conditions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moldiag.de/en/dis/bartter.htm |title=Hereditary disease: Bartter syndrome |publisher=Moldiag.de |date= |accessdate=2012-09-28}}</ref>. *neurological abnormalities such as [[anencephaly]], which impair the swallowing reflex. Anencephaly is failure of close of the rostral neuropore (rostral neural tube defect). If the rostral neuropore fails to close there will be no neural mechanism for swallowing. *chromosomal abnormalities such as [[Down syndrome]] and [[Edwards syndrome]], (which is itself often associated with GI abnormalities). *Skeletal dysplasia, or dwarfism. There is a possibility of the chest cavity not being large enough to house all of the baby's organs causing the trachea and esophagus to be restricted, not allowing the baby to swallow the appropriate amount of amniotic fluid.
*sacrococcygeal teratoma
==Diagnosis== There are several pathologic conditions that can predispose a pregnancy to polyhydramnios. These include a maternal history of [[diabetes mellitus]], [[Rh incompatibility]] between the fetus and mother, intrauterine infection, and [[multiple birth|multiple pregnancies]].
During the pregnancy, certain clinical signs may suggest polyhydramnios. In the mother, the physician may observe increased abdominal size out of proportion for her weight gain and gestation age, uterine size that outpaces gestational age, shiny skin with stria (seen mostly in severe polyhydramnios), dyspnea, and chest heaviness. When examining the fetus, faint fetal heart sounds are also an important clinical sign of this condition.
==Associated conditions== Fetuses with polyhydramnios are at risk for a number of other problems including [[cord prolapse]], [[placental abruption]], premature birth and perinatal death. At delivery the baby should be checked for congenital abnormalities.
==Treatment== Mild asymptomatic polyhydramnios is managed expectantly. A woman with symptomatic polyhydramnios may need hospital admission. [[Antacids]] may be prescribed to relieve heartburn and [[nausea]]. No data support dietary restriction of salt and fluid.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} In some cases, [[amnioreduction]], also known as therapeutic [[amniocentesis]], has been used in response to polyhydramnios.<ref name="pmid15301292">{{cite journal |vauthors=Piantelli G, Bedocchi L, Cavicchioni O, etal |title=Amnioreduction for treatment of severe polyhydramnios |series=75 |journal=Acta bio-medica : Atenei Parmensis |volume=Suppl 1 |issue= |pages=56–8 |year=2004 |pmid=15301292 |doi=}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Amniotic fluid index]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = 10319 | ICD10 = {{ICD10|O|40||o|30}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|657}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = 003267 | eMedicineSubj = radio | eMedicineTopic = 566 | MeshID = D006831 }}
* {{Chorus|00329}}

[[Category:Unidentified murder victims in California]] [[Category:1979 deaths]] [[Category:People from Rancho Cucamonga, California]] [[Category:People who were forensically reconstructed]] [[Category:Unidentified American children]] [[Category:20th-century deaths]] [[Category:Deaths by beating in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths from asphyxiation]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in the United States]] [[Category:1979 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Murdered American children]]

The '''Reynolds–Sorgi Incident''' refers to an American [[college football]] in-game incident in which [[Ohio State Buckeyes]] linebacker [[Robert Reynolds (football player)|Robert Reynolds]] choked [[Wisconsin Badgers]] quarterback [[Jim Sorgi]], injuring Sorgi's [[Vertebrate trachea|trachea]], after the play had been whistled dead. Sorgi was unable to play for the remainder of the game, struggling to breathe and unable to speak.
==The game== On October 11, 2003, the Buckeyes entered the game as the defending national champions, ranked #3 in the country and on a 19-game winning streak with a record of 5–0. The unranked Badgers came into the game at 5–1, having lost at home to UNLV. The Badgers were without star running back Anthony Davis, who was recovering from a fractured eye-socket caused by a late-hit. The game was played at the Badgers' home [[Camp Randall Stadium]].
Midway through the third quarter, Sorgi scrambled for an eight-yard gain before being brought down by a convergence of OSU tacklers. After the play was called dead, Reynolds grabbed Sorgi's throat with his hand as Sorgi lay on his back. Sorgi's vocal cords were bruised, he had a hard time breathing, and he was unable to speak. He would not return to the game, and though Reynolds was not whistled for a foul, the Badgers came back to win the game.
After the game, [[Big Ten]] commissioner [[James Delany]] commented, "(Reynolds' actions) have no place in our game." Buckeyes coach [[Jim Tressel]] initially claimed he didn't see the play but later said "Robert's conduct was totally unacceptable and has no place in intercollegiate athletics." Ohio State suspended Reynolds for one game and Reynolds issued a public apology.
Years later, on October 28, 2011, Robert Reynolds came forward to make another public apology, stating that he wanted to put the incident behind him and teach his four children about being accountable and moving on from their mistakes. Reynolds also said that he and Sorgi had made amends not long after the incident occurred, something for which Reynolds said he was very grateful.
==External links== *[http://www.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/stories/101103aei.html CSTV story on the game]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Reynolds-Sorgi incident}} [[Category:American football incidents]] [[Category:2003 Big Ten Conference football season]] [[Category:College football controversies]] [[Category:Ohio State Buckeyes football]] [[Category:Wisconsin Badgers football]] [[Category:Violence in sports]] [[Category:2003 in Wisconsin]]
