revision.text:
{{other people|Susan Anderson}} {{Infobox person | name = Susan Anderson | image = File:Susan Anderson.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = January 31, 1870 | birth_place = [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1960|04|16|1870|01|31}} | death_place = [[Denver, Colorado]] | other_names = | education = [[University of Michigan]] | module = {{Infobox medical details | profession = Physician | field = | work_institutions = | specialism = | research_field = | prizes = }}}} '''Susan Anderson''' (January 31, 1870 – April 16, 1960) was an American [[physician]] and one of the first women to practice medicine in [[Colorado]].<ref name=cvl>{{cite web|url=http://coloradovirtuallibrary.org/content/susan-anderson|title=Susan Anderson, Mountain Doctor|work=Colorado Virtual Library|publisher=Colorado State Library|accessdate=June 1, 2014}}</ref>
==Biography== Anderson was born in 1870 in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]], and later moved to [[Kansas]]. Her parents divorced when she was young, and she lived with her father, younger brother, and grandmother. After she graduated from high school in 1891, her family moved to [[Cripple Creek, Colorado]] after gold had been discovered there. Although she originally wanted to work as a [[telegraph operator]], she was encouraged by her father to attend medical school at the [[University of Michigan]].<ref name=cvl/>
Anderson became a licensed physician after graduating from medical school in 1897. She returned to Cripple Creek before moving around Colorado in attempt to practice in [[Denver]], [[Greeley, Colorado|Greeley]] and [[Eaton, Colorado|Eaton]], but found it difficult to find work.<ref name=cvl/><ref name=cgw>{{cite web|url=http://www.cogreatwomen.org/index.php/item/104-susan-anderson|title= Susan "Doc Susie" Anderson|publisher=[[Colorado Women's Hall of Fame]]|accessdate=June 1, 2014}}</ref> She was briefly engaged but was left at the altar by her fiancé in 1900.<ref name=bhm>{{cite web|url=http://businessheroinemagazine.com/heroine-of-history-susan-anderson/|title=Heroine of History – Susan Anderson: Care-taker for All|first=Kat|last=Michels|date=June 14, 2013|work=Business Heroine Magazine|accessdate=June 1, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140602204117/http://businessheroinemagazine.com/heroine-of-history-susan-anderson/|archivedate=June 2, 2014|df=}}</ref> In 1904, she was appointed Coroner of [[Grand County, Colorado]], during which time she investigated many of the deaths involved in the construction of the [[Moffat Tunnel]] railroad.<ref name=cgw/>
After contracting [[tuberculosis]] in 1907, Anderson relocated to [[Fraser, Colorado]], where residents affectionately nicknamed her "Doc Susie"; for 49 years, she was the only physician in Fraser.<ref name=cgw/><ref name=post>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.denverpost.com/library/2012/07/11/doc-susie-fraser-colorado/2301/|title="Doc Susie" of Fraser, Colorado|date=July 11, 2012|work=[[The Denver Post]]|accessdate=June 1, 2014}}</ref> She tended to a range of patients and medical conditions including childbirth, skiing injuries, and particularly [[pneumonia]] during the [[1918 flu pandemic]]. Although most of her work involved making house calls to patients, Anderson never owned a horse or car, and she was usually paid in food or firewood rather than money.<ref name=cgw/> [[File:Susan Anderson, Mount Pisgah Cemetery.JPG|thumb|left|Her grave in Mount Pisgah Cemetery (Cripple Creek, Colorado)]] During the 1950s, Anderson was the focus of several newspaper and magazine stories. Actress [[Ethel Barrymore]] offered to make a film about Anderson's life, but the latter declined.<ref name=cgw/> Anderson retired in 1956 and was admitted to [[Denver General Hospital]] with poor health in 1958, where she stayed until her death; she died in 1960, aged 90, and was buried in Cripple Creek.<ref name=bhm/>
Anderson was inducted into the [[Colorado Women's Hall of Fame]] in 1997.<ref name=cgw/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Commons category|Susan Anderson}} {{Colorado Women's Hall of Fame |state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Anderson, Susan}} [[Category:1870 births]] [[Category:1960 deaths]] [[Category:American women physicians]] [[Category:American coroners]] [[Category:People from Grand County, Colorado]] [[Category:People from Cripple Creek, Colorado]] [[Category:People from Fort Wayne, Indiana]] [[Category:Physicians from Colorado]] [[Category:University of Michigan Medical School alumni]] [[Category:People of the American Old West]]

page.title: Under Secretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence

revision.text:
The '''Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence''' is a position within the [[United States Department of the Treasury]] responsible for directing the Treasury's efforts to cut the lines of financial support for terrorists, fight financial crime, enforce economic sanctions against [[rogue nations]], and combat the financial support of the proliferation of [[weapons of mass destruction]]. The Under Secretary is appointed by the [[President of the United States|President]] and confirmed by the [[United States Senate|Senate]].
The current Under Secretary is [[Sigal Mandelker]], appointed by President [[Donald Trump]], and confirmed to the position by the Senate on June 21, 2017.<ref>https://www.congress.gov/nomination/115th-congress/172</ref>
==Overview== The Under Secretary heads the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence (TFI), created under 31 USC 312, when the administration of President [[George W. Bush|Bush]] announced on May 8, 2004, that the Executive Office of Terrorist Financing and Financial Crimes (TFFC), the [[Financial Crimes Enforcement Network]] (FinCEN), the [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]] (OFAC), and allocated resources from the Treasury Department would be brought under the new office's control. The Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence also possesses oversight of the Office of Intelligence and Analysis, created under 31 USC 311, [one of sixteen agencies in the United States Intelligence Community per 50 USC 3003]. <ref>{{cite web | title=Bush Administration Announces Creation of New Office in Ramped up Effort to Fight the Financial War on Terror | url=http://www.treas.gov/press/releases/js1219.htm | accessdate= September 21, 2007 }}</ref> The [[Federal Reserve]] remains outside the jurisdiction of this office, and cannot be investigated by it.{{Citation needed|date=April 2014}}.
==History== The position's predecessor, the Under Secretary for Enforcement, managed law enforcement aspects of the Department prior to the reorganization. The Under Secretary for Enforcement provided oversight and policy guidance for the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms]], the [[U.S. Customs Service]], the [[Federal Law Enforcement Training Center]]; the [[Financial Crimes Enforcement Network]], the [[U.S. Secret Service]], the Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture, and the [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]]. The Under Secretary also provided policy guidance over the [[Internal Revenue Service]]'s Crime Investigation.<ref name="b">{{cite web | title=U.S. Treasury - Biography of Jimmy Gurule, Under Secretary for Enforcement | url=http://www.treas.gov/organization/bios/gurule-e.html | accessdate= September 21, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071003045324/http://www.treas.gov/organization/bios/gurule-e.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = October 3, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=U.S. Treasury - Duties & Functions of the Under Secretary of Enforcement | url=http://www.treas.gov/education/duties/treas/u-sec-enforcement.shtml | accessdate= February 13, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060213064754/http://www.treas.gov/education/duties/treas/u-sec-enforcement.shtml |archivedate = February 13, 2006}}</ref>
Several of these agencies are now non-existent or have been moved into other federal departments. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms was split into two separate bureaus, with one handling certain law enforcement aspects and the other handling tax collection aspects. The former was moved into the [[United States Department of Justice]], while the latter was kept within the Department of the Treasury.<ref>{{cite web | title=About TTB:Home | url=http://www.ttb.gov/about/index.htm | accessdate= June 18, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060618080606/http://www.ttb.gov/about/index.htm |archivedate = June 18, 2006}}</ref> The U.S. Secret Service and the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center are now within the [[Department of Homeland Security]].<ref>{{cite web | title=United States Secret Service: History | url=http://www.ustreas.gov/usss/history.shtml | accessdate= September 21, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071004233514/http://www.ustreas.gov/usss/history.shtml <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = October 4, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Welcome to FLETC — Federal Law Enforcement Training Center | url=http://www.fletc.gov/ | accessdate= September 21, 2007 }}</ref> The U.S. Customs Service was moved into the Department of Homeland Security when it became part of the [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]].<ref>{{cite web | title=CBP.gov - home page | url=http://www.cbp.gov/ | accessdate= September 21, 2007 }}</ref> However, under the Homeland Security Act of 2002<ref name="Homeland Security Act of 2002">[[Homeland Security Act of 2002]] Homeland Security Act of 2002</ref> Custom Service's "revenue functions" were retained by Treasury. This includes, among others, Customs duties, enforcing trade agreements, and counterfeit trademark detection and seizure.<ref name="detection.">[http://law.onecle.com/uscode/06/215.html] 6 U.S.C. § 215.</ref>
==Former Under Secretaries== Former Under Secretaries of include [[Jimmy Gurule]],<ref name="b"/> [[Jim_Johnson_(politician)|James Johnson]],<ref>{{cite web | title=Nominations Sent to the Senate | url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2001/04/20010430-4.html | accessdate= September 21, 2007 }}</ref> [[Raymond Kelly]],<ref>{{cite news|title=12 in Ariz. militia unit arrested Paramilitary members accused of plotting to destroy federal offices|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1996-07-02/news/1996184056_1_ammonium-nitrate-viper-militia-paramilitary|accessdate=May 15, 2014|newspaper=The Sun|date= July 2, 1996}}</ref> [[Ronald Noble]]<ref>{{cite web | title=Secretary General | url=http://www.interpol.int/Public/ICPO/Governance/SG/noble.asp | archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20010924221504/http://www.interpol.int/public/icpo/governance/sg/noble.asp | dead-url=yes | archive-date=September 24, 2001 | accessdate=September 21, 2007 }}</ref>, Stuart Levy, and [[David S. Cohen (attorney)|David Cohen]]. [[Adam Szubin]] was appointed Under Secretary under the Obama administration but was never confirmed by the Senate.
==See also== *[[Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
